Patient Care

The UCSF Division of General Internal Medicine aspires to excellence in patient care. Our clinics are located at UCSF Medical Center at Parnassus and Mt. Zion, San Francisco General Hospital, and the VA Medical Center.

 

UCSF Division of General Internal Medicine provides care at these locations:

UCSF Screening and Acute Care Clinic
400 Parnassus Ave., First Floor
San Francisco, CA 94122
Patient Line: 415-353-2602

UCSF General Internal Medicine Clinics at Mt. Zion
1545 Divisadero Street, 1st and 2nd Floors
San Francisco, CA 94115
Patient Line: 415-353-7900
1701 Divisadero Street, 5th Floor
San Francisco, CA 94115
Patient Line: 415-353-7999

General Internal Medicine at San Francisco General Hospital
1001 Potrero Avenue
Main Hospital - GMC 1M3
San Francisco, CA 94110
Patient Lines: (415) 206-8494, (415) 206-3833

General Internal Medicine at San Francisco VA Medical Center
4150 Clement Street
Building 200, First Floor
San Francisco, CA 94121
Phone: 415-750-2129

What to Bring to Your Appointment

  • Health insurance information including authorizations or referrals
  • List of prescription medications and dosages
  • List of medications that you're allergic to
  • List of questions you may have
  • Recent test results related to your condition
  • Paper and pencil to take notes

node.FileBody:
The Division of General Internal Medicine at UCSF

The origins of DGIM are in the Division of Ambulatory and Community Medicine (ACM), directed by Robert H. Crede, MD, before the Dean split ACM into two units – DGIM and a new Department of Family and Community Medicine.

The Division of General Internal Medicine’s (DGIM) "founding father" was Steve Schroeder, M.D. DGIM was established because the then Department of Medicine (DOM) Chairman, Dr. Holly Smith, was following the general internal medicine movement nationally and felt that University of California San Francisco (UCSF) could use such a division. Dr. Smith selected Dr. Schroeder to be Chief; planning began in 1979 and opened on July 1980. Subsequently, separate DGIM units were established at the San Francisco General Hospital under the leadership of Richard Haber, MD and at the San Francisco Veterans Administration Hospital under the leadership of Gerald Charles, MD. Currently, the Department of Medicine at UCSF houses three autonomous Divisions of General Internal Medicine at the Mount Zion/Parnassus campus of the UCSF Medical Center, the San Francisco Veterans Affairs Medical Center and the San Francisco General Hospital Medical Center. Each division is governed separately within the three medical centers housing robust research and creative scholarship programs, extensive clinical services in the ambulatory setting and are primarily responsible for the training in ambulatory general internal medicine for over 150 medicine residents each year.

Together, these three divisions make up about 25% of all salaried faculty within the Department of Medicine and have key leadership positions within the Department as associate chairs for ambulatory care and strategic planning and as associate directors of the residency program. The three DGIM units collaborate on multiple research projects, educational programs and Continuing Medical Education Courses.

Mt. Zion/Parnassus Division of General Internal Medicine

The Division of General Internal Medicine at Mt Zion/Parnassus was established in 1980 and has grown to more than 80 faculty members, 69 internal medicine residents (including 30 primary care residents) and more than 150 staff. Our general medicine practice serves a diverse population of about 25,000 patients and is certified as a level 3 NCQA Patient Centered Medical Home. We are proud of the quality care we deliver to patients with complex chronic illness and the high marks we receive in patient satisfaction scores.

DGIM faculty researchers focus on a broad spectrum of disease and population-based research including patient-doctor communication, tobacco control, geriatric care, informatics, genetic epidemiology, cancer prevention, health disparities, cardiovascular disease risk, diabetes and medical decision making. Many of our faculty are well funded by federal research funding, and are nationally recognized for their work. DGIM teaches outpatient general internal medicine to residents and students through continuity and urgent care experiences. As one of the leading primary care residency programs in the nation, the UCSF Primary Care Internal Medicine Residency trains residents to care for complex patients in the ambulatory and hospital settings.

We are also committed to medical student education through all four years of the curriculum. The culture of DGIM is based on humanism, integrity in science and patient care, commitment to social justice, value added in diversity and collective responsibilities and rewards.  

Mitchell D. Feldman, MD, MPhil, FACP
Professor of Medicine and Chief, DGIM
Associate Vice Provost, Faculty Mentoring

San Francisco General Hospital Division of General Internal Medicine

Our goal is to be the best public hospital Division of General Internal Medicine in the country. We aim to deliver innovative, comprehensive and complex primary care to San Francisco’s vulnerable patients; carry out highly impactful translational research to improve the health of vulnerable populations; to engage in meaningful policy work focused on reducing health disparities and ensuring access to care for vulnerable populations; and to train the next generation of physician leaders in (a) the care of the underserved, (b) research and policy for the underserved, and (c) education regarding the care of the underserved.

Dean Schillinger, MD
UCSF Professor of Medicine in Residence
Chief, Division of General Internal Medicine
San Francisco General Hospital
University of California, San Francisco

Veterans Affairs Medical Center Division of General Internal Medicine

The Division of General Internal Medicine at the San Francisco Veterans Affairs Medical Center strives to provide outstanding and innovative service to our nation’s Veterans through excellence in our core missions of patient care, research and education. Our three primary care clinics – Medical Practice at SFVAMC, and the San Bruno and downtown San Francisco community-based outpatient clinics – have implemented a patient-centered medical home model that is integrated with ground-breaking, educational programs for learners from multiple disciplines. Our researchers are working to improve the future of healthcare for both Veterans and non-Veterans by investigating disease processes, designing novel treatment strategies, and by eliminating systematic barriers to optimal healthcare delivery.

Michael Shlipak, MD
UCSF Professor of Medicine in Residence
Chief, Division of General Internal Medicine
Veterans Affairs Medical Center
University of California, San Francisco

2017 Crede Awards

The annual DGIM Robert H. Crede Awards provide the faculty and staff of Mt. Zion DGIM an opportunity to recognize their co-workers for their dedication and service to the Division, our students, our patients and the community. Nominations for each of the categories were submitted by DGIM faculty and staff and the winners were selected by the Crede Award Committee composed of last year's winners.

Congratulations to the winners and nominees!

2017 Crede Awards Winners (with excerpts from nominations)

Excellence in Teaching - Maki Aoki, MD
Maki has been an outstanding addition to our teaching faculty. Residents rave about her teaching both on Wedneday mornings and in urgent care. She creates a positive learning climate for all learners and finds the clinical “pearls” in each encounter.

Excellence in Clinical Care - Don Ng, MD
Don embodies what all of us aspires to be in a clinician. He loves his patients and practices patient centered care. And his love for his job is contagious. He is also known as a clinician that speaks out for minority patients and their needs. I can’t imagine a physician that is more deserving of this award.

Excellence in Clinical Research - Alison Huang, MD, MAS
Alison is an extremely smart, diligent, researcher in women’s health with admirable focus and conviction. She has pursued exciting new R01s over the past year investigating peri-menopausal symptoms and overactive bladder – two issues which are critical for women’s health yet remain understudied. She never hesitates to share her expertise, make time to support junior faculty and is always thoughtful and prolific in her work.

Excellence in Nursing Care - Marquesa Sunga, LVN
Marquesa is absolutely phenomenal LVN to work with. Our team is so lucky to have her. She is highly skilled as an LVN with excellent communication skills, attention to detail, forethought, compassion and efficiency. She is an amazing resource for her teammates and our patients. Our residents have loved working with her.

Excellence in Academic Administration - Susana Szeto
Susana is one of the research financial analysts with the academic office. She is very knowledgeable on grant financials and policies. Susana is always willing to assist you on any requests or questions you send her way. Also, she will teach and guide you navigate through difficult UCSF processes. She has been a tremendous asset to the division and well-deserved to be recognized for her contribution to the division.

Excellence in Clinical Administration - LaToyia Gilmore, MA
LaToyia is an amazing staff member and nurse and I can’t believe she hasn’t won this award before! She is smart, insightful, wonderful with patients, and very professional. The fact that she can do front-desk work with patients as well as nursing jobs makes her invaluable. There is no situation she can’t handle. Patients love her and I feel very lucky to work with her on a daily basis and on the same clinical team.

Excellence in Community Service - Brent Kobashi, MD
Brent volunteers at the Berkeley Free Clinic as the shift professional. He takes care of patients who have no other source of care, offering general care and screening and treating STIs. He also mentors students interested in a career in healthcare. He volunteered there in college and it’s wonderful that he’s gone back to volunteer again.

The Division of General Internal Medicine at UCSF accepts gifts to help support our missions of delivering high quality health care and training the best doctors of the future. For more information, please contact Olivia Herbert.

Olivia Herbert
Senior Director of Development, UCSF
220 Montgomery Street, 5th Floor
San Francisco, CA 94104

Office Tel: (415) 476-9878
Mobile Tel: (415) 676-8942
Email: oherbert@support.ucsf.edu

Recently Established Chairs

Stephen J. McPhee, MD Endowed Chair

Stephen J. McPhee, MD

Over the past 30 years, Dr. Stephen J. McPhee has been the core of the Division of General Internal Medicine and the primary care residency program. Dr. McPhee is the rare educator who has significantly improved general medicine education nationally and consistently inspires individual trainees locally. He is one of UCSF's most-respected clinicians, is the Division's most highly sought-after clinical preceptor, and is a source of friendship and personal strength to residents, graduates and faculty.

In recognition of his outstanding contributions to the Division of General Internal Medicine and the primary care training program, the Division has elected to establish the Stephen J. McPhee, MD Endowed Chair at UCSF.

A permanent endowment in Dr. McPhee’s name will be a lasting tribute to Dr. McPhee, but will also provide important resources to support the career of a faculty member in the Division of General Internal Medicine. The Chair will be awarded to a faculty member who shares Dr. McPhee's incredible dedication to delivering the highest quality of care to patients while at the same time maintaining a passionate commitment to providing the best training for our residents.

To give to the Stephen J. McPhee, MD Endowed Chair, please visit https://makeagift.ucsf.edu/SMcPhee

Gifts From Generous Donors

Deborah L. Faiman Young Investigator Travel Award

The Deborah L. Faiman UCSF Young Investigator Travel Award assists in the travel costs for a resident or fellow in the Division of General Internal Medicine to attend a domestic scientific meeting/conference. This generous gift is made possible by Ms. Deborah L. Faiman.

Robert H. Crede, MD

Dr. Crede was born in Chicago August 11, 1915 and received his BA from the University of California, Berkeley in 1937 honored with Phi Beta Kappa. He received his MD at UCSF in 1941 and was awarded the Gold Headed Cane at graduation. After serving as an intern at San Francisco General Hospital (1941-1942), he entered the U.S. Army for three years as a member of the 30th General Hospital. Dr. Crede returned to UCSF as a resident in Medicine (1944-1946) and later chief resident (1946-1947). He married Marjorie Lorain on August 29, 1947 and they had three children. From 1947 to 1949 he was a Commonwealth fellow in psychosomatic medicine at the University of Cincinnati. The comprehensive, bio-psychosocial model approach to patients learned during that fellowship had a significant effect on his subsequent professional life. In 1949, Dr. Crede returned to UCSF on faculty in the Department of Medicine, served as assistant dean (1955-1960) and associate dean (1960-1973), and became a full professor in 1960. From 1980 to 1986, Dr. Crede served as associate dean for academic affairs. He elected emeritus status in 1986 but continued to be active in the school until 1989.

In 1965, Dr. Crede assumed responsibility for a major clinical service of the Department of Medicine when he became director of the Comprehensive Medical Clinics. In 1966 he established the Division of Ambulatory and Community Medicine and was the first Chief; he involved the four UCSF schools in this endeavor (Nursing, Dentistry, Pharmacy, Medicine). In collaboration with David Werdegar, H. Vandervoort,,Dace Mitchell, Mary Malloy, Donald Fink, Joseph Barbaccia, Nancy Byl, H.Chinn, H.Werdegar, and Barbara Resnik, they developed the first interdisciplinary, inter-school ambulatory clerkship for medical students, the first such in the U.S. In 1980 from this autonomous Division of Ambulatory and Community Medicine in the School of Medicine came the Division of General Internal Medicine and the Department of Family and Community Medicine. Again he employed a comprehensive solution in structuring the model academic unit and its educational programs, drawing on faculty and students from many disciplines. From its inception, the division of Ambulatory and Community Medicine (ACM) became a model care setting for the nation with its focus on primary medical care. Later, the division began a postdoctoral and post-residency fellowship in Ambulatory and Community Medicine. A series of bold new programs followed: a residency in Primary Care General Internal Medicine in 1974; a residency in General (primary care) Pediatrics in the Department of Pediatrics; and a residency in Family Practice at the San Francisco General Hospital. These training programs, developed under the leadership of Dr. Crede, were effectively husbanded by this dedicated, wise visionary in his capacity as honored and uncompromising academician, gentle, firm educator and careful, diplomatic statesman, but most of all a superb clinician and accessible and encouraging mentor.

In 1972, ambulatory clinical services moved into the new Ambulatory Care Center that Dr. Crede envisioned, planned, and helped set up. The building, renamed the Robert H. Crede Ambulatory Care Center in 1994 at the suggestion of Joseph Martin, chancellor of UCSF, stands today as a clinical service center and as a tribute to a man who gave so much to the campus from 1949, when he joined the faculty, until 1989, when he finally retired. Dr. Crede passed away on February 21, 1996. Marjorie Crede lives in Moraga, daughter Victoria lives in Fair oaks and Christina lives in the East Bay. His son Bill graduated from UCSF School of Medicine and went to Yale for internal medicine residency and remained there on the faculty.

Richard Haber, MD

Richard "Rick" Haber was the pioneering founder of San Francisco General Hospital's Division of General Internal Medicine and its primary care residency track of the UCSF internal medicine residency. For many years, Rick was the inspiration and force that made it all work. Thanks to his vision, energy and spirit, we continue to have a unique residency training program that attracts the best medical students in the country for outstanding clinical training for a career in caring for underserved and vulnerable patients.

Until the end, Rick was a passionate voice for medical education. He was a teacher among teachers and an advocate for this role even as the ever growing business model of medicine tried to squeeze the opportunities for reflection and learning out of our system. Rick loved to teach and he always did so in a way that made a learner feel more confident and less alone. He had a unique ability to calmly guide third year medical students during their first clinical experiences in medicine. Rick was also a cherished resource for the housestaff and faculty. His door was always open to whoever had a clinical question.

After consulting with Rick's family and with faculty at San Francisco General Hospital who knew him best, we have decided to establish a fund in Rick's name that would enable us to invite nationally recognized teachers of primary care to visit San Francisco General Hospital on an annual basis. The visiting professor would provide a Grand Rounds talk on primary care medical education and be available to meet with residents, students and faculty in the Division with the hope that through this event we could help to keep Rick's dream of support for medical education alive and meaningful for generations of primary care doctors to come.

DGIM Honorary Lectureships

The Crede Lectureship

The Crede Lectureship honors Robert H. Crede, MD, Professor of Medicine at UCSF (1949-1989), who was a national champion of primary care. Dr. Crede developed comprehensive ambulatory medical services at UCSF and also changed pre-doctoral and postdoctoral medical education to emphasize a comprehensive approach to all patient problems, especially in the ambulatory and home settings. The honor of hosting The Crede Lecture is shared and rotated by the Division of General Internal Medicine of the Department of Medicine, the Department of Family and Community Medicine and the Division of General Pediatrics of the Department of Pediatrics.

Haber Visiting Lectureship

Every year in the fall, the SFGH Division of General Internal Medicine invites a pre-eminent, national leader in primary care practice and education to visit UCSF/SFGH for the Richard J. Haber, MD Memorial Lectureship. Dr. Haber was a tireless teacher of primary care and clinical GIM, with a focus on both medical student and resident learners. After a stint in the Public Health Service, he dedicated his career to this work, teaching young people how to practice good medicine for the underserved. He passed away a few years ago and a lectureship was created both to honor his memory, as well as inspire sustained commitments to teaching primary care and to provide contact with leaders in primary care education and scholarship for aspiring UCSF faculty, fellows and house-staff and students.

The invited speaker gives a Grand Rounds Lecture that aligns thematically with Rick’s passions as well as attends residents' report and meets with key GIM / SFGH faculty and fellows from SFGH and the other UCSF campuses, all at SFGH. Four prior speakers have been Gordie Schiff (Cook County, now Brigham), Faith Fitzgerald (UC Davis), Jack Ende (U Penn), and Clarence Braddock (Stanford)

The Division of General Internal Medicine is located and managed de-centrally at three campuses of the University of California, San Francisco: the UCSF Medical Center at Mt. Zion, the San Francisco General Hospital Medical Center, and the San Francisco VA Medical Center.

Each site has its own uniqueness but all excel in the delivery of high quality, culturally sensitive and linguistically appropriate primary and preventive health care; conducting innovative, population-based and epidemiological research; and training the best doctors of the future.

The Division of General Internal Medicine is located and managed de-centrally at three campuses of the University of California, San Francisco: the UCSF Medical Center at Mt. Zion, the San Francisco General Hospital Medical Center, and the San Francisco VA Medical Center.

Each site has its own uniqueness but all excel in the delivery of high quality, culturally sensitive and linguistically appropriate primary and preventive health care; conducting innovative, population-based and epidemiological research; and training the best doctors of the future.

Parnassus/Mount Zion

The Parnassus/Mount Zion campus is a tertiary referral center for patients with gastrointestinal and liver diseases. This campus is home to the UCSF Liver Transplant Program, which performs > 150 liver transplants annually, and the Inflammatory Bowel Disease Center, which is active in the study of new treatments for ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. The campus is a major northern California referral center for advanced endoscopy. Programs in GI cancers are also run from this campus, in conjunction with oncologists at the Helen Diller Family Comprehensive Cancer Center.

View Map
Parnassus/Mount Zion Campus – GI Administrative Office
513 Parnassus Avenue
Room S-357
San Francisco, CA 94143 (view map)

San Francisco General Hospital (SFGH)

San Francisco General Hospital (SFGH) is the focal point of the city’s safety-net healthcare system and a Level 1 trauma center. This site is a center of excellence in health care for HIV-infected patients and a leader in the delivery of GI specialty care to ethnically diverse, underserved patient populations. GI physicians at SFGH have received recognition for training mid-level professionals to perform endoscopy; the division has also successfully implemented immunohistochemical fecal occult blood testing (FIT) within the safety-net system as an economical approach to colon cancer screening. SFGH is the administrative home of the UCSF Liver Center, a multidisciplinary research consortium focusing on liver biology and disease.

View Map
San Francisco General Hospital Campus – GI Administrative Office
1001 Potrero Avenue
Room 3D-7
San Francisco, CA 94110 (view map)

San Francisco VA Medical Center (SFVAMC)

The San Francisco VA Medical Center (SFVAMC) provides GI specialty care in gastroenterology and hepatology to veterans throughout northern California. This site is a center of excellence in advanced endoscopy, inflammatory bowel disease, and chronic liver disease. To meet the needs of this underserved, geographically diverse population, providers have implemented a successful tele-medicine program. GI faculty at the SFVAMC study novel endoscopic methods for evaluating diseases of the luminal GI tract and pancreas, chronic viral hepatitis, and helped develop national practice guidelines and patient/provider information to optimize the management of veterans with HCV infection.

View Map
San Francisco VA Medical Center Campus – GI Adminstrative Office
4150 Clement Street
Room 111-B
San Francisco, CA 94121 (view map)

SFGH Division of General Internal Medicine Staff Bios

Purba Chatterjee, MPH

Purba is the Manager for the Center for Vulnerable Populations (CVP) in the Division of General Internal Medicine at the San Francisco General Hospital and Trauma Center. As Manager for the CVP, Purba facilitates strategic planning, program development, networking with collaborators, fundraising activities, dissemination efforts and relationship building with various stakeholders. Purba is also the Project Manager for an NIH funded Comprehensive Center of Excellence known as the Center for Health And Risk in Minority youth and adults (CHARM). Prior to this position, Purba directed the International Training and Education Center on Health (I-TECH), a collaborative project between UCSF and University of Washington based in Chennai, India. Purba has over ten years of public health program management experience. She has an undergraduate degree in Economics from University of California, Los Angeles and a Master's degree in Public Health from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine (LSHTM). Purba has worked with HIV positive vulnerable populations in San Francisco, and internationally in Uganda and India.

Victoria Chen

Victoria did her undergraduate degree in public health and gender studies at the Johns Hopkins University. She then worked in Taiwan for three years as editor and writer at an international publishing company before moving back home to California. She joins the Division of General Internal Medicine as program coordinator for PROF-PATH, a research and academic career development program directed by Dr. Alicia Fernandez.

node.Fname: Center for Aging in Diverse Communities ./dgim/cadc/index.html
node.FileBody:
Minority populations and persons of less privileged socioeconomic status suffer a disproportionate burden of disease and associated complications from many serious health conditions in the U.S. In addition, as the U.S. population ages, older persons as a group are increasingly more ethnically diverse with social and behavioral factors predicting substantial variation in functioning and morbidity in older adults. To address these issues, the Center for Aging in Diverse Communities (CADC) was established at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF) in 1997. CADC is one of six national Centers funded by the Resource Center for Minority Aging Research (RCMAR) program by the National Institute on Aging (NIA), National Institutes of Health.

The CADC is committed to increasing high quality research focused on the concerns of aging Latinos and African Americans by:

  • Increasing the number of researchers devoted to improving the health of minority older adults and reducing health disparities.

  • Developing and mentoring minority researchers by providing training, mentoring and support of pilot studies.

  • Collecting and validating existing measures for research with minority adults and developing new measures.

  • Recruiting and retaining minority older adults for clinical research.

  • Funding and implementing new pilot studies that advance knowledge on healthy aging, disease, and disability among older minority adults.

  • Disseminating information about interventions to reduce disease and disability and improve the health of older minority adults.

Follow us on Facebook!

 

 
Recent News

Leah Karliner, MD, MAS, appointed as the new Director of the Center for Aging in Diverse Comminities. Dr. Karliner is Associate Professor in Residence in the Division of General Internal Medicine, Department of Medicine at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF). Her research is focused at the nexus of health disparities, health communication, and systems interventions to improve quality of care delivery for older patients. She has focused her communication work on under-served and high-risk patients, their families, and communities. She has expertise in diverse participant recruitment, survey-based research design, as well as implementation and evaluation of technology-mediated interventions.

Read More

Maria Chao, DrPH, MPA, Associate Professor and CADC pilot study recipient, was awarded a $2 million grant from the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute. Her project, entitled “Nonpharmacologic Approaches to Relieve Pain and Symptom Distress among Diverse Hospitalized Cancer Patients,” will investigate best approaches to combining medications and non-drug treatments to improve pain management for diverse cancer patients.

Julene K Johnson, PhD, CADC Faculty member and Professor was appointed as the interim Associate Dean of Research in the UCSF School of Nursing. She began her new 50% position on September 1, 2017.

Nynikka Palmer, DrPH, MPH, Assistant Professor and CADC pilot study recipient, will receive a KO1 Career Development Award from the National Cancer Institute. Her project, entitled “Constructing a Relational Bridge to Achieve High-Quality Prostate Cancer Care for African Americans,” will investigate the potential of grounding a peer navigation intervention in the relational concept of African American brotherhood to address disparities among African American men with prostate cancer.

Laura Fejerman, PhD, Associate Professor and CADC pilot study recipient, was awarded an R01 from the National Cancer Institute. Her project, entitled, “Biological implications of breast cancer protective variants in Latin American women with high Indigenous Ancestry,” will investigate the underlying biology of protective breast cancer genetic variants among Latina women.

Jason Flatt, PhD, Assistant Professor and CADC pilot study recipient, was awarded two grants, one from the UCSF Hellman Fellows Fund and a KL2, to study the epidemiology of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias in sexual and gender minority older adults.

Elizabeth Rose Mayeda, PhD, Postdoctoral Scholar and CADC pilot study recipient, has accepted a position as a tenure-track Assistant Professor in the Department of Epidemiology at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Public Health starting in January 2018.

CONGRATULATIONS TO ALL OF OUR CADC SCIENTISTS!

The mission of the Center is to decrease ethnic and racial disparities in health by focusing attention on healthy aging among older minority populations.

The Center addresses this mission by serving as a catalyst for investigators conducting research that focuses on African American, Latino and Asian elderly. We provide funding for new pilot studies and mentor minority researchers, thereby increasing the number of researchers dedicated to improving the health of diverse older adults. We also focus on improving research methods and measures for diverse populations, as well as on the recruitment and retention of minorities in research projects. 

The Center participates in community outreach and continues to sustain and expand its partnerships with diverse communities of color in the San Francisco Bay Area, working to achieve mutual trust and respect between community-based organizations and UCSF. We collaborate with community-based organizations to identify areas of interest and priorities, facilitate communication between research institutions, individuals and organizations and thus ensure that our research is responsive to the needs of older minority individuals.

The Center is composed of four separate but integrated units: Administrative Core, Investigator Development Core, Measurement Core, and Community Liaison Core.
Recent News
The GI Oncology group are the inaugural recipients of the Helen Diller Family Quality Award. The group is led by gastrointestinal cancer expert Alan Venook, MD, and includes Andrew Ko, MD, Michael Korn, MD, and Emily Bergsland, MD.
The SFGH Medical Service has honored Judith Luce, MD (Subspecialist Consultant of the Year Award), Philip Hopewell, MD (John F. Murray Award), and Edward Lor, PharmD (Consultant of the Year Award) for their dedication to education, patient care, and the humanitarian mission of the hospital.
Eric Goosby, MD, a leader in the fight against the AIDS epidemic, was confirmed by the Senate as the new US global AIDS coordinator.

The Seal of the University of California

The mission of the Center is to decrease ethnic and racial disparities in health by focusing attention on healthy aging among older minority populations.


The Center addresses this mission by serving as a catalyst for investigators conducting research that focuses on African American, Latino and Asian elderly. We provide funding for new pilot studies and mentor minority researchers, thereby increasing the number of researchers dedicated to improving the health of diverse older adults. We also focus on improving research methods and measures for diverse populations, as well as on the recruitment and retention of minorities in research projects.

The Center participates in community outreach and continues to sustain and expand its partnerships with diverse communities of color in the San Francisco Bay Area, working to achieve mutual trust and respect between community-based organizations and UCSF. We collaborate with community-based organizations to identify areas of interest and priorities, facilitate communication between research institutions, individuals and organizations and thus ensure that our research is responsive to the needs of older minority individuals.

Leah Karliner, MD, MAS, is the Director of the Center for Aging in Diverse Communities

Dr. Karliner is Associate Professor in Residence in the Division of General Internal Medicine, Department of Medicine at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF). In addition to being the new Director of the Center on Aging in Diverse Communities, she is also a member of the Multiethnic Health Equity Research Center at UCSF as well as the UCSF Helen Diller Family Comprehensive Cancer Center. She is both a practicing general internist and a health services and implementation science researcher. She received her BA in History from Columbia University. She completed her medical and research training - including her MD degree, a residency in primary care internal medicine, a general internal medicine research fellowship and a Master’s of Advanced Studies in Clinical Research - at UCSF.

Her research is focused at the nexus of health disparities, health communication, and systems interventions to improve quality of care delivery for older patients. She has focused her communication work on under-served and high-risk patients, their families, and communities. She has expertise in diverse participant recruitment, survey-based research design, as well as implementation and evaluation of technology-mediated interventions. She is currently PI or co-PI on two NIH funded grants and one Patient Centered Outcomes Research Insitute (PCORI) contract. Her PCORI funded study is aimed at evaluating communication and process outcomes with older Spanish, Chinese and English-speaking primary care patients before and after implementation of enhanced professional interpreter services and clinician certification of bilingual language skills. Her NCI funded study is designed to identify actionable systems and communication factors contributing to timely or untimely follow-up for minority women after an abnormal mammogram. Dr. Karliner is co-PI on an NIDDK funded pragmatic RCT of an electronic health record-based clinical decision support tool for primary care physicians to deliver guideline driven care for chronic kidney disease. All of these studies focus on systems and communication approaches to improving care and reducing disparities for an aging, diverse population.


leah.karliner@ucsf.edu
Anita Stewart, PhD, is the Analysis Core Leader. She is Professor Emerita at the Institute for Health & Aging at UCSF. She has extensive experience conceptualizing and measuring health, functioning, well-being, social support, physical activity, quality of care, and other health-related concepts. As director of the Analysis Core, she identifies issues in using measures that have been tested primarily on mainstream groups in studies of diverse population groups, and how to test the conceptual and psychometric adequacy of those measures.
anita.stewart@ucsf.edu
Steve Gregorich, PhD, is the Analysis Core Co-Leader and member of the Investigator Development Core. He is Professor of Medicine in the Division of General Internal Medicine at UCSF. He is an applied statistician with interest in behavioral public health research related to prevention. His methodological interests focus upon analysis of longitudinal and clustered data; structural equation models with latent variables; analysis with missing data; statistical power; and psychometrics.
steven.gregorich@ucsf.edu
Celia P. Kaplan, DrPH, MA, is a Leader of the Community Liaison Core and Investigator Development Core member. She is a Professor in the Department of Medicine, UCSF. She is the Director of the The Multiethnic Health Equity Research Center (MERC). A Latina researcher, she holds a doctorate in public health and a master’s degree in Latin American studies from the University of California, Los Angeles. Her past, current and future projects attest to her commitment to cancer prevention and control among minority populations. Dr. Kaplan is the Co-Director of the Minority Task Force, which promotes recruitment and retention of minorities into UCSF cancer-related clinical research projects.
celia.kaplan@ucsf.edu
Julene Johnson, PhD, is a Community Liaison and Investigator Development Core member. She is a cognitive neuroscientist and Professor at the UCSF Institute for Health & Aging. Her research program focuses on cognitive aging and covers two primary themes: 1) developing cost-effective and novel community-based programs to promote health for diverse older adults and 2) studying mild cognitive impairment as a risk for dementia and functional decline. She is currently collaborating with 12 Department of Aging and Adult Services Senior Centers in San Francisco to study the effect of a community choir program on the health and well-being of diverse older adults. She is currently on the Fulbright Specialist Roster (2012-2017).
julene.johnson@ucsf.edu
Tung Nguyen, MD, is the Co-Leader of the Community Liaison Core and Investigator Development Core member. He holds several health disparities-focused leadership positions, e.g., Dean's Diversity Leader in charge of Diversity in Research, Director of the Asian American Research Center on Health. Dr. Nguyen was Chair of President Obama’s Advisory Commission on Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders from 2014-2017. He has conducted numerous community-engaged research projects with Asian American populations, including RCTs of interventions to promote cancer screening and hepatitis B and C testing.
tung.nguyen@ucsf.edu

node.Fname: Center for Aging in Diverse Communities - About Us ./dgim/cadc/about/index.html
node.FileBody:
The mission of the center is to decrease ethnic and racial disparities in health by focusing attention on healthy aging among older minority populations.

The center addresses this mission by serving as a catalyst for investigators conducting research that focuses on African American, Latino and Asian older adults. We provide funding for new pilot studies and mentor minority researchers, thereby increasing the number of researchers dedicated to improving the health of ethnically diverse older adults. We also focus on improving research methods and measures for diverse populations, as well as on the recruitment and retention of minorities in research projects.

The center participates in community outreach and continues to sustain and expand its partnerships with diverse communities of color in the San Francisco Bay Area, working to achieve mutual trust and respect between community-based organizations and UCSF. We collaborate with community-based organizations to identify areas of interest and priorities, facilitate communication between research institutions, individuals and organizations and thus ensure that our research is responsive to the needs of older minority individuals.

The center is composed of four separate but integrated units: administrative core, investigator development core, analysis core, and community liaison core.

  • Administrative Core:  The administrative core of the CADC is the central organizational unit that coordinates and supports the work of the investigator development, measurement and community liaison cores. The goals of the administrative core reflect the overall goals of the center.

  • Investigator Development Core: The investigator development core of the CADC funds less experienced minority investigators (CADC scholars) to conduct pilot studies to investigate issues of aging in African American, Latino and Asian American populations.  This core also provides training and mentoring to develop the research skill and independent research careers of these CADC scholars.

  • Analysis Core:  The analysis core works to clarify issues regarding how well various measures work in different racial or ethnic groups and provides methodological guidance in conducting health disparities research.

  • Community Liaison Core:  The community liaison core has developed credible partnerships with community organizations serving older Latinos, Asians, and African Americans conducts research on the science of recruitment, and builds academic-research partnerships.

Liliana Chacón, BS, is CADC’s Administrative Coordinator. Ms. Chacon holds a BS degree in Community Health Education and has experience conducting behavioral research in diverse populations, including conducting focus groups, semi-structured interviews, database creation and management, and web site development.
liliana.chacon@ucsf.edu

Jasmine Santoyo-Olsson, MSc, is CADC’s Project Coordinator. She has been project director on many projects that focus on patient-clinician communication, cancer disparities among underserved older adults, and community-based models of research and service delivery in ethnically and socioeconomically diverse groups.
jasmine.santoyo-olsson@ucsf.edu

node.Fname: Community Liaison Core: Community Advisory Board ./dgim/cadc/community/advisoryboard.html
node.FileBody:
The Community Advisory Board of the CADC is a diverse group of community, clinical and academic representatives whose purpose is to assist and advise the CADC in fulfilling its mission. The members provide CADC with input on the needs and priorities of older ethnically diverse communities in the San Francisco Bay Area.

Caregiver Resources

We provide caregive resources for adults aged 65 and older in the San Francisco Bay Area. 

Hands-on Daily Help

  • Home Care Assistance provides primary live-in home care or back-up caregivers who stay in the home 24 hours a day, seven days a week for homebound older adults. Also provide hourly home care.
  • Contact information: (866) 454-8346 (4-LiveIn); San Francisco (415) 904-1085; Peninsula (650), 462-6900; and East Bay (925) 820-8390. 

Legal Services

  • National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys assists seniors and people with special needs with public benefits, probate and estate planning, guardianship/ conservatorship, and health and long-term care planning, among other important issues.

On-line Information

  • Alzheimer’s Association provides support, advice, and information for all those affected by Alzheimer’s and related dementias; and help people find clinical trials.

  •  Alzheimer’s Foundation of America (AFA) AFA and/or their member organizations offer all or most of the following services: toll-free hotline, education, social services, care connection, professional development, and advocacy to improve the quality of life for those with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. Also provides a free quarterly magazine for caregivers called “Advantage.”

  • Medicare provides basic information, related topics and links. 

  • National Institute on Aging the Alzheimer's Disease Education and Referral (ADEAR) Center Web site will help you find current, comprehensive Alzheimer's disease information and resources from the National Institute on Aging.

  • Retirement Basics for Seniors here you will find information on Social Security, Retirement Planning, State Taxation, Pensions, Medicare and Medicaid, Long Term Care and more.

    • Caregiver and Family Support

    • Family Caregiver Alliance provides information, education, services, research and advocacy to those caring for people with chronic, disabling health conditions. Website available in English, Spanish and Chinese.

      • Contact information: 180 Montgomery Street; San Francisco, CA, 94194; (415) 434-3388 or (800) 445-8106. 

    • Eldercare Locator a public service of the U.S. Administration on Aging connecting you to services for older adults and their families.You can also reach them at (800) 677-1116.

      • Top

The CADC faculty is dedicated to disseminating current information on health disparities research.  CADC faculty offer a yearly course on health disparities research methods, which covers key conceptual and methodological considerations in conducting clinical research in ethnically diverse populations. 

Along with the Medical Effectiveness Research Center for Diverse Populations (MERC), the CADC co-sponsors monthly seminars on recent studies conducted by findings from health disparities researchers.

We highlight a few projects of the Community Liaison Core below.
 

Current projects







The Community of Voices/Comunidad de Voces is a research study that is examining whether singing in a community choir is a cost-effective way to promote health and well-being among culturally diverse older adults. Enrollment is now closed and data analyses are underway. The principal investigator is Julene K Johnson, PhD, a Professor at the UCSF Institute for Health & Aging and UCSF Center for Aging in Diverse Communities. For this cluster-randomized clinical trial study, new choirs for older adults were started in 12 senior centers throughout San Francisco. Participants in the study sang in a choir for one year and completed several health assessments. The Community of Voices/Comunidad de Voces study is a three-way partnership between the University of California San Francisco (UCSF), the San Francisco Community Music Center, and 12 San Francisco Department of Aging and Adult Services (DAAS) senior centers. The study is funded by a grant to UCSF from the National Institute on Aging of the National Institutes of Health (award number R01AG042526).

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26463176

 







Nuevo Amanecer II is a community-engaged RCT that is testing the effectiveness of an evidence-based stress management program for Spanish-speaking Latina breast cancer survivors living in three rural California communities: Imperial Valley, Visalia, and Watsonville/Salinas. We are enrolling eligible women through approximately March 2018, for this free, 10-week program that is delivered by trained breast cancer survivors in participants’ homes. If you are interested, please contact Jasmine (Spanish-English bilingual) at (855) 755-8273 or at jasmine.santoyo-olsson@ucsf.edu . Participants receive up to $100 for completing 3 surveys. This project is supported by funds from the California Breast Cancer Research Grants Program Office of the University of California, Grant Number 21OB-0135 (PI: Anna Nápoles).

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25905829
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28275966
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24577971
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18340533

 

Recent projects







Live Well, Be Well was a translational research study to evaluate the effectiveness of a community-based lifestyle diabetes risk reduction program designed for lower socioeconomic status, minority, and Spanish-speaking adults at risk of diabetes. The project was a partnership between the University of California San Francisco (UCSF) and the City of Berkeley Division of Public Health (BDPH). The Live Well, Be Well program was evaluated through a 1-year randomized controlled trial by UCSF. The individually-tailored lifestyle program, Live Well, Be Well, is available in English and Spanish and provided education and skills training to improve diet and increase physical activity. The curriculum and health education materials used in the Live Well, Be Well program are available online and include technical assistance to people interested in adapting the program for use in other communities. For more information see http://iha.ucsf.edu/LiveWellBeWell/.

This project was funded by a translational research grant (R18 DK067896) from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases made to Anita Stewart, PhD, PI.

 







Training Latino Caregivers to Promote Aging in Place was a capacity-building demonstration project that provided caregiver training to promote healthy aging in the Latino community by working with community-based organizations on program design and implementation. Based on survey data gathered from about 100 community-based organizations serving older diverse adults in Southern and Northern California and input from organizations, the investigators developed 4 caregiver training modules in English and Spanish: Effective Communication and Caregiving; Managing Stress for Caregivers; Legal Planning for Caregivers; and Financial Planning for Caregivers. The team is seeking additional funding to evaluate the effectiveness of the program. This project was funded by Archstone Foundation Grant No. 14-04-62 (Celia Kaplan, PI).

 

  Top

Celia Kaplan, Leader; Tung Nguyen, Co-Leader; Julene Johnson, member.

The Community Liaison Core (CLC) of the CADC is the unit of the Center that focuses on the development and maintenance of academic-community partnerships. The mission of the CLC is to foster mutually beneficial academic-community partnerships to promote health and healthy aging among ethnically diverse older adults. Our faculty and staff facilitate aging research in ethnically diverse populations and provide technical assistance to community partners who would like to become involved in minority aging research. Our research is enriched by the colorful mosaic that is the ethnically and linguistically diverse San Francisco Bay Area population.

Our Aims

  • Provide support to CADC Scientists (junior minority investigators - see investigator core) and other UCSF aging researchers to engage minority communities in minority aging research.

  • Maintain a collaborative network of community and faith-based organizations to enhance the engagement of communities of color and sexual and gender minorities in minority aging research.

  • Disseminate information on state-of-the-art recruitment and retention methods for health disparities research.

node.Fname: Community Liaison Core: Minority Older Adults in the Bay Area ./dgim/cadc/community/minorityolderadults.html
node.FileBody:
We provide resources for and about minority older adults in living in the San Francisco Bay Area.

San Francisco Bay Area Data
We provide California Health Interview Survey (CHIS) data for adults aged 65 and older in the San Francisco Bay Area by racial/ethnic groups.  It provides a snapshot on general demographics.  Counties considered include: Alameda, Contra Costa, San Francisco, San Mateo, and Santa Clara.  We also provide data for the state of California for comparison purposes.

Alameda County tables – demographics

Contra Costa County tables – demographics

San Francisco County tables – demographics

San Mateo County tables – demographics

Santa Clara County tables – demographics

California tables – demographics

Tables were created using AskCHIS. AskCHIS draws upon the responses of more than 50,000 Californians interviewed by The California Health Interview Survey (CHIS) – the largest state health survey in the United States.

Learn More

    ClinicalTrials.gov is a free database of federally and privately supported clinical trials conducted in the United States and around the world. ClinicalTrials.gov gives you information about a trial's purpose, who may participate, locations, and phone numbers for more details.

    ResearchMatch has a simple goal – to bring together people who are trying to find research studies, and researchers who are looking for people to participate in their studies.  ResearchMatch is a free and secure registry that has been developed by major academic institutions across the country who want to involve you in studies trying to make a real difference for everyone’s health in the future.
    BreastCancerTrials.org is a nationwide clinical trial matching service. Users can screen for trials personalized to their situation and, with the help of the locater tools, find research sites across the country.  BreastCancerTrials.org includes trials across the spectrum of breast health and features easy-to-read trial summaries, online HELP as well as phone and email support

Resource Centers for Minority Aging Research

Events

 

ON LOK

ON LOK'S 30TH STREET SENIOR SERVICES 225 - 30th Street (between Dolores and Church) 415-550-2210

On Lok's 30th Street Senior Services provides a spectrum of care for seniors in the Mission, Noe Valley, Diamond Heights, Glen Park and St. Mary's Park neighborhoods of San Francisco.
30th Street Nutrition Program: 30th Street's Nutrition Program provides hot, nutritious midday meals at seven sites throughout San Francisco six days per week. Home delivered meals, including therapeutic meals for people requiring special diets, are also provided to home-bound seniors. Call 415/550-2225 for more information.
30th Street Senior Center: Receive assistance with social services, ranging from translation services to referral services; participate in health promotion activities; attend exercise and art classes; meet other seniors from the community at 30th St. Senior Center. Call 415/550-2210 for more information.
Bilingual Case Management: English-Spanish bilingual case manager coordinates and facilitates access to a variety of services for seniors who need assistance in organizing and managing their care. Call 415/550-2230 for more information.
Senior Central #5: A one-stop neighborhood-based resource center for seniors living in the Mission, Noe Valley, Bernal Heights and Buena Vista districts. Call or drop in for information regarding how to obtain housing, adult day care, transportation, citizenship, caregiving, social and in-home support services. Assistance is free and available to all seniors over the age of 55. Call 415-920-0588 for more information.

Resource Centers for Minority Aging Research

Events

 

Central American Resource Center

Central American Resource Center
1245 Alabama St.,
San Francisco, CA 94110
(415) 824-2330

The (CARECEN) was established in 1986 by the Salvadoran refugee community in order to respond to issues concerning Central American refugees. From the mid-1940s through the 1970s, trickles of Central American individuals and families immigrated to Northern California. In the 1980s, violent civil wars, political repression and economic hardship forced a mass exodus of Central Americans from their homelands. Many of these refugees, after living in the United States for more than ten years, have made this country their permanent home. Estimates of the Central American population in the Bay Area range up to 200,000 persons with 80,000 to 120,000 people living in San Francisco.
CARECEN is located in San Francisco’s Mission District, a densely populated area which is home to a high concentration of low-income Latino families. The area also has the largest concentration of youth and children per square mile in San Francisco.

Community Served

As new immigrants from Latin America move toward successful integration into U.S. society, they are faced with a variety of political, social and economic problems, including poor living conditions, cultural and language barriers, inaccessible health and other services, and lack of training and education to compete in a tight job market.

Mission

CARECEN serves as a bridge to self-empowerment for the Central American and other Latino immigrant communities of Northern California. CARECEN implements services that address the immediate legal, health, educational, social and economic needs and rights of this population. In doing this, CARECEN aims to improve the quality of life and to promote healthy families. At the same time, CARECEN works to empower the population to advocate for and affect permanent political and social justice.

CARECEN’s Programs

CARECEN faces the difficult task of developing integrated programs that not only directly serve the needs of our community, but also promote organization through direct community involvement in planning and decision making. With a staff of 17 and an active volunteer corps of over 50, CARECEN provides services and education to over 10,000 persons annually in the following areas:

  • Health
    Health projects are coordinated through the Center's Celina Ramos Clinic for the immigrant, homeless and/or low-income communities, located at the CARECEN site. The Clinic is staffed almost entirely by a volunteer professional medical and dental team working alongside community volunteers to promote preventive care and education. General health services include a dental clinic, women’s wellness and prenatal clinic, an immunization clinic, and community health education and outreach programs.

  • Family Resource System
    CARECEN forms part of this broad-based community collaborative offering an integrated, early-intervention service system for Latino families. The system allows CARECEN to better identify, serve and follow-up on the multiple needs of high-risk Latino families through case-management and counseling. The system includes an effective referral system, monitoring and documentation, as well as logistical support in a decentralized and effective manner so as to preserve and strengthen Latino families.
    CARECEN also works to reduce violence and encourage community by organizing parent groups, participation in the Second Chance Tattoo Removal Program, offering education and services for victims of domestic violence and serving as a site for the District Attorney’s Victim Witness Assistance Program.

  • Legal Services
    CARECEN provides legal services, representation and education in immigration matters to low-income Latino immigrants. The department boasts an expertise in emergency-oriented legal services and short-term windows of opportunity offered by the INS. The department is well known for its political asylum work and, throughout its ten-year history, has maintained a 100% success rate in its asylum cases, as compared to a national approval rate of less than 10%. In addition to the full range of immigration legal services offered, CARECEN also runs voter registration campaigns and promotes naturalization as a part of its citizenship program. It is responsible for informing the community of current and relevant issues in immigration.

  • Jovenes Unidos (Newcomer Youth)
    The Jovenes Unidos Program is a CARECEN-led collaborative providing comprehensive social, acculturation, educational and recreational activities for Latino immigrant youth ages 6-13 who have been in the United States for five years or less. The project combines case management services with an after-school program of academic enrichment, ESL instruction and tutoring, recreation, arts and cultural studies, homework assistance, and computer training.

  • Parent Empowerment
    The project has evolved out of Jovenes Unidos bi-monthly parent meetings, by which parents helped determine the orientation and emphases of the Jovenes Unidos afterschool program serving their children. Through these meetings the parents of Jovenes Unidos participants began to express their own needs for strengthening their families and to prioritize those needs. The three goals of the project are: (1) to enable Jovenes Unidos parents to actively support the educational success of their children through high school; (2) to equip Jovenes Unidos parents with skills and knowledge in order to open doors of economic and social opportunity in their new country; and (3) to empower Jovenes Unidos parents to serve as role models within their families and communities. This is accomplished through family empowerment workshops and job skills trainings.

  • Grassroots Organizing
    Education to the community on relevant issues is done continuously through outreach and mass communication in Spanish. When the information is critical, radio spots are paid for. Presently four campaigns are being carried out: (1) legal permanent residency for political asylum applicants from Guatemala and El Salvador and for Nicaraguans, (2) US citizenship followed up with voter registration and civic education, (3) support and links to a grassroots democracy and civic education campaign in El Salvador and (4) participation in and solidification of local and national coalitions, such as Salvadoran-American National Network (SANN) working for social justice. CARECEN’s own client constituency is mobilized to participate in promoting the campaign objectives through peer advocacy, congressional visits, community forums, letter and petition signing, etc.

CENTRO DE RECURSOS CENTROAMERICANOS

CARECEN

The Central American Resource Center (CARECEN) was established in 1986 by the Salvadoran refugee community in order to respond to issues concerning Central American refugees. From the mid-1940s through the 1970s, trickles of Central American individuals and families immigrated to Northern California. In the 1980s, violent civil wars, political repression and economic hardship forced a mass exodus of Central Americans from their homelands. Many of these refugees, after living in the United States for more than ten years, have made this country their permanent home. Estimates of the Central American population in the Bay Area range up to 200,000 persons with 80,000 to 120,000 people living in San Francisco.
CARECEN is located in San Francisco’s Mission District, a densely populated area which is home to a high concentration of low-income Latino families. The area also has the largest concentration of youth and children per square mile in San Francisco.

Community Served

As new immigrants from Latin America move toward successful integration into U.S. society, they are faced with a variety of political, social and economic problems, including poor living conditions, cultural and language barriers, inaccessible health and other services, and lack of training and education to compete in a tight job market.

Mission

CARECEN serves as a bridge to self-empowerment for the Central American and other Latino immigrant communities of Northern California. CARECEN implements services that address the immediate legal, health, educational, social and economic needs and rights of this population. In doing this, CARECEN aims to improve the quality of life and to promote healthy families. At the same time, CARECEN works to empower the population to advocate for and affect permanent political and social justice.

CARECEN’s Programs

CARECEN faces the difficult task of developing integrated programs that not only directly serve the needs of our community, but also promote organization through direct community involvement in planning and decision making. With a staff of 17 and an active volunteer corps of over 50, CARECEN provides services and education to over 10,000 persons annually in the following areas:
  • Health
    Health projects are coordinated through the Center's Celina Ramos Clinic for the immigrant, homeless and/or low-income communities, located at the CARECEN site. The Clinic is staffed almost entirely by a volunteer professional medical and dental team working alongside community volunteers to promote preventive care and education. General health services include a dental clinic, women’s wellness and prenatal clinic, an immunization clinic, and community health education and outreach programs.
  • Family Resource System
    CARECEN forms part of this broad-based community collaborative offering an integrated, early-intervention service system for Latino families. The system allows CARECEN to better identify, serve and follow-up on the multiple needs of high-risk Latino families through case-management and counseling. The system includes an effective referral system, monitoring and documentation, as well as logistical support in a decentralized and effective manner so as to preserve and strengthen Latino families.
    CARECEN also works to reduce violence and encourage community by organizing parent groups, participation in the Second Chance Tattoo Removal Program, offering education and services for victims of domestic violence and serving as a site for the District Attorney’s Victim Witness Assistance Program.
  • Legal Services
    CARECEN provides legal services, representation and education in immigration matters to low-income Latino immigrants. The department boasts an expertise in emergency-oriented legal services and short-term windows of opportunity offered by the INS. The department is well known for its political asylum work and, throughout its ten-year history, has maintained a 100% success rate in its asylum cases, as compared to a national approval rate of less than 10%. In addition to the full range of immigration legal services offered, CARECEN also runs voter registration campaigns and promotes naturalization as a part of its citizenship program. It is responsible for informing the community of current and relevant issues in immigration.
  • Jovenes Unidos (Newcomer Youth)
    The Jovenes Unidos Program is a CARECEN-led collaborative providing comprehensive social, acculturation, educational and recreational activities for Latino immigrant youth ages 6-13 who have been in the United States for five years or less. The project combines case management services with an after-school program of academic enrichment, ESL instruction and tutoring, recreation, arts and cultural studies, homework assistance, and computer training.
  • Parent Empowerment
    The project has evolved out of Jovenes Unidos bi-monthly parent meetings, by which parents helped determine the orientation and emphases of the Jovenes Unidos afterschool program serving their children. Through these meetings the parents of Jovenes Unidos participants began to express their own needs for strengthening their families and to prioritize those needs. The three goals of the project are: (1) to enable Jovenes Unidos parents to actively support the educational success of their children through high school; (2) to equip Jovenes Unidos parents with skills and knowledge in order to open doors of economic and social opportunity in their new country; and (3) to empower Jovenes Unidos parents to serve as role models within their families and communities. This is accomplished through family empowerment workshops and job skills trainings.
  • Grassroots Organizing
    Education to the community on relevant issues is done continuously through outreach and mass communication in Spanish. When the information is critical, radio spots are paid for. Presently four campaigns are being carried out: (1) legal permanent residency for political asylum applicants from Guatemala and El Salvador and for Nicaraguans, (2) US citizenship followed up with voter registration and civic education, (3) support and links to a grassroots democracy and civic education campaign in El Salvador and (4) participation in and solidification of local and national coalitions, such as Salvadoran-American National Network (SANN) working for social justice. CARECEN’s own client constituency is mobilized to participate in promoting the campaign objectives through peer advocacy, congressional visits, community forums, letter and petition signing, etc.

<title>Department Of Medicine</title>

Center for Elders Independence is a nonprofit organization founded in 1988 through a joint effort by the Community Adult Day Health Services, Inc (CADHS) and the Over 60 Health Center, Inc. It's mission is to provide a comprehensive approach to serving elders so that they can stay at home and in the community.

In 1992, CEI became one of a few sites around the country to implement the PACE Program. PACE stands for Program of All-Inclusive Care for the Elderly. Using Medi-Cal and Medicare waivers, the PACE model of care assumes full financial responsibility for the care of all enrolled participants. The patient pool of funds covers all the health and health-related needs of its participants. CEI has been operating as a PACE program replication site since 1992. As a PACE site, CEI operates a comprehensive, coordinated home and day program based out of Highland Hospital in East Oakland and The San Pablo located at 1955 San Pablo in Central Oakland.

Our programs target the very impaired and frail elderly who meet Medi-Cal eligibility criteria for nursing home-level care. By joining in this program, participants receive a wide range of social, medial and health supportive services that help them maximize their health and independence and stay in the community. Without PACE, most participants would be living in nursing home facilities; many placed far away from family and other community ties.
The services available through the program are:
  • In-home services, such as personal care, chore and errand services
  • Day Health care: rehabilitation, medical care, hygiene help and social/ recreational care
  • Primary and urgent care through the day health center or as needed
  • Medications
  • Acute Hospital and Skilled Nursing Facility Care
  • Medical Specialty Services
  • Laboratory/X-Ray/Ambulance Service
  • Restorative/Supportive Services
CEI is licensed by the California Department of Health Services as a primary health care clinic, adult day health center, and home care agency. Bipartisan federal lawmakers have supported the PACE model since it's inception. In Fall of 1997, federal legislation moved PACE from demonstration to provider status. There are currently 156 frail elders enrolled in CEI's program.
Center for Elders Independence
1955 San Pablo Ave.,
Oakland CA 94612
(510) 433-1150
Client Profile
Average age: The average age of CEI participants is 74 (the median is 78 years).
Gender: 63 percent of CEI participants are female. 37 percent of CEI participants are male.
Ethnicity : 87 percent of our participants are African American; five percent are Caucasian; three percent are Hispanic; one percent are Asian or Pacific Islander; one percent are American Indian.
Living Situation: 37 percent of CEI participants live at home with others; 35 percent live in a congregate care facility; 21 percent live at home alone; four percent are currently in nursing homes.
Medicare/Medicaid Eligibility: 95% of CEI participants are eligible to receive Medicare benefits (parts A and B) and Medicaid.; 2% are eligible for Medicare (part B only) and Medicaid; 1% are eligible for Medicaid only.
SSI Eligibility: 65 % of CEI participants receive SSI benefits.
Monthly income: 72% of participants receive a total monthly income between of $500 and $799.
Common medical conditions: Most of the participants at CEI have several medical conditions, among these are hypertension, diabetes, cerebral vascular disease, congestive heart failure, incontinence and dementia.
Activities of Daily Living: 88% of our participants need assistance with bathing; 82% with grooming; 77% with dressing; 57% with toileting; 49% with transferring (wheelchair to bed, to car, etc.); 52% with walking; 64% with feeding.
Instrumental Activities of Daily Living: 99% of CEI participants need assistance with meal preparation, housework, and transportation; 97% need assistance with shopping; 96% with laundry, 91% with taking medications.
Family Situation: 49% of CEI participants are widowed; 36% are divorced or separated; 9% are married. 28% of CEI participants have four or more living children; 25% have two or three living children: 24% have no living children; 22% have one living child.
Ten Most Frequently Asked Questions About CEI
1. What is the Center for Elders Independence?
CEI is an innovative, all-inclusive, long-term health care program for the frail elderly which allows them to live independently in the community and get all the care they need. We are a Health Plan which provides all medical care (24-hours -a-day), an adult day health care center, home care services, and transportation.
2. What do you mean "frail elderly"?
A person qualifies as "frail elderly" if he/she is 55 years of age or older and has health problems that prevent them from living independently.
3. How does a person qualify to join CEI?
A person qualifies if he or she: Is age 55 or older; Is a resident of Oakland; and, Has health problems that limit his or her independence.
4. What kinds of services does CEI provide those who participate?
Those who qualify to participate in CEI receive 100% of the following services at no cost to them: ALL physician, specialist and nursing care; ALL prescription drugs and durable equipment; ALL dental, eye and foot care; ALL hospital care, emergency and nursing home care; ALL rehabilitative therapies
5. How much does CEI cost?
If you are eligible for Medi-Cal and Medicare, the services described above are covered in full as a benefit. We also accept private pay clients.
6. How would I get to CEI (and what would I do when I got there)?
We'll pick you up at home in one of our specially equipped vans, and bring you to CEI for the day. You will get a medical clinic check-up, physical and occupational therapy (if you need it!), a hot meal, plus social and recreational activities with other active Oakland seniors at our adult day health care center.
7. What if my health limited me from coming to CEI- Are there any in-home services I would receive?
Those who are eligible will receive In-Home Care Services (of course, these services must be necessary and you must be approved to receive them), including:
-Personal care (bathing, grooming, dressing), and
-Housekeeping (cleaning, cooking, laundry, shopping).
8. What about my personal doctors?
Those who participate agree to receive all health care services directly from CEI's medical team, made up of physicians, nurses, social workers, therapists (physical, occupational and speech), and others who work at CEI. As a member of CEI you'll have access to medical care 24-hours a day, 7-days a week, 365-days a year.
CEI's goal is to design a total health care program specifically for you, based on your needs, and coordinate your medical care, therapy, nutrition, recreational therapy, in-home care, hearing, foot, dental, and eye care and medications together.
9. If I wanted to join CEI, how can I qualify?
First we schedule a home visit with you and your family, to tell you more about CEI. Next we arrange a tour of the Center for you and your family, and finally schedule a complete medical assessment for you by our team.
10. How can I get more information?
CEI's Health Plan Representatives are available at (510) 433-1150. They can answer all your questions and arrange a personal interview and tour for you.
Enrollment is now open for this program. Call to ensure that you have a health plan you can depend on as you grow older, so that you may face the future with peace of mind and a sense of security.

<title>Department Of Medicine</title>

Mission Statement

The Network for Elders (Network) is a creative and non-traditional organization recognized as the source of comprehensive services that enhance independence and quality of like for Bayview Hunters Point frail elders and their families. The Network is a dedicated voice for the elderly in this primarily African American community.

Current Programs and Activities

1) Case Management

Through case management services, the Network links informal and formal support systems into a plan of coordinated care for frail elders. Case managers conduct home visists and return as often as necessary to establish rapport, build trust and determine clients' strengths and needs. They develop a coordinated care plan, determine entitlement eligibility, interpret forms and instructions, act as liaison/advocate and arrange or provide transportation.
A component of the case management program is "Helping Hands at Home", a program designed to employ Bayview Hunters Point residents as care workers in the homes of low-income frail elders in the community. The Network maintains eight to ten attendants on staff who work in the homes of our clients. The clients pay the Network $4-$10.00/hour, depending on the ability to pay. The Network supplements the fees so that the workers receive fair wages, basic benefits, holiday, sick and vacation pay.

2) Interfaith Volunteer Program

Project VOICE ( Volunteers Offering Information and Companionship to Elders) is an interfaith volunteer caregiver program partially funded by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. The volunteer manager has enlisted local churches and youth programs to form a coalition to provide a framework for the volunteer services to be performed. The coalition has elected its own leaders, including representatives from each church involved. The program now offers phone reassurance, yard work/minor home repairs, friendly visiting, respite assistance, grocery shopping, and transportation.

3) Wellness Program/Breast Health Education Program

The Network offers workshops and classes on issues such as breast health and arthritis. We also publish articles on health issues pertinent to the African American senior community in our quarterly newsletter, Senior Wisdom. Future expansion possibilities include in-service training, community education, medication information, exercise, nutrition, flu shots, prevention or early detection programs for cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular problems and dementia as well as mental health programs to assist with alcoholism and other drug related illnesses.

Annual Events

The Network holds several annual special events. Every Spring, we present 'Seniors' Night Out" with Neighborhood Elders Support Team and Planning for Elders in the Central City. The goal is to provide San Francisco seniors with a fun night out in which they are the honorees. In November, the Network holds its annual Community Recognition Gala in which we honor individuals form San Francisco who have contributed to the cause of frail elders. In December, we host a holiday luncheon specifically for BHP seniors. The same week-- with the help of volunteers--we deliver holiday food boxes to BHP seniors who cannot afford the special foods that are traditionally associated with holiday celebrations.
