REACH/ALCANCE

REACH/ALCANCE (Resources for Enhancing Alzheimer’s Caregiver Health): “A study for family caregivers” is a unique five year, multi-site collaborative study funded by the National Institutes of Health, the National Institute on Aging and the National Institute of Nursing Research. REACH investigates the effectiveness of various interventions for family caregivers and has six intervention sites located throughout the United States.

In northern California REACH/ALCANCE (its name in Spanish) is conducted by the Older Adult and Family Center as part of the Veterans Affairs Palo Alto Health Care System and Stanford University School of Medicine.
REACH/ALCANCE offers support services to Latino and Anglo women coping with the stress associated with caring for a family member or loved one with memory loss. Services include Telephone Support, Support Groups and “Coping with Caregiving" classes that all help caregivers learn ways to reduce their stress and cope with caregiving while increasing their contact with others who understand their needs. All support services are offered in English and Spanish by a team consisting of bicultural and bilingual professionals.
REACH/ALCANCE services are free of charge, and financial assistance is available as needed for transportation and elder care costs incurred while attending REACH/ALCANCE activities. Please contact Ana Menéndez or Kellie Takagi at (650) 617-2774 or (650) 617-2669 for more information.

Resource Centers for Minority Aging Research

Events

 

Cores

Administrative Core
The Administrative Core of the CADC is the central organizational unit that coordinates and supports the work of the Investigator Development, Measurement and Community Liaison Cores. The goals of the Administrative Core reflect the overall goals of the Center.

Investigator Development Core
The Investigator Development Core of the CADC has three components. First, we fund less experienced minority investigators to conduct pilot studies to investigate issues of aging in African American, Latino and Asian American populations.

Measurement Core
The Measurement Core works to clarify issues regarding how well various measures work in different racial or ethnic groups.

Community Liason Core
The Community Liaison Core has developed a community-based infrastructure that is exemplified by relevant and credible partnerships with community organizations serving older Latinos and African Americans and promoting programs in healthy aging.
     

Home | News & Events | Donate | Links | Contact | Webmaster
Copyright © 2003, The Regents of University of California. All rights reserved.

The Investigator Development Core of the RCARDP will have two major components. First, we will select and fund pilot studies to investigate issues of aging in African American and Latino populations. These pilot studies will be led or co-led by minority investigators at the junior faculty level and supervised by the RCARDP's core faculty as well as affiliated aging researchers at UCSF. Second, the Investigator Development Core will create a program to disseminate research information to all potentially interested audiences including community-based organizations, health care professionals and trainees, and opinion leaders within the African American and Latino communities. Our Specific Aims for this Core are:
  1. To establish a network of researchers with expertise in minority health and aging to select pilot studies to be funded, and then assist and mentor these less experienced minority investigators in conducting their pilot studies.
  2. To fund a minimum of fifteen pilot studies over five years including three in year 1 which will be led or co-led by a minority investigator.
  3. To assist minority investigators funded by the pilot studies to develop and submit an independent research proposal based on the data collected.
  4. To establish a program for dissemination of research information regarding techniques used for conducting research involving African American and Latino aging populations.

Diverse Communities (CADC) ensures the representation and participation of African American and Latino community members in aging research by bridging the resources of communities and research institutions. The Community Liaison Core creates linkages between research institutions and community based organizations that aim to decrease racial and ethnic disparities in the health of older African Americans and Latinos. An infrastructure at CADC is being developed to support the on-going participation of community-based organizations and ethnically-diverse populations in aging research to address issues of concern to African American and Latino communities. In addition, the center is establishing a community-based network to facilitate the recruitment and retention of research participants in clinical, behavioral, epidemiological and social science studies conducted by investigators affiliated with the Resource Centers for Minority Aging Research (RCMAR), as well as other researchers focused on the health of minority populations. The community liaison core develops and evaluates effective channels both local and national to address the need to disseminate research methodologies and recruitment strategies. Dissemination of this information is an essential part of the plan to increase the participation of culturally diverse older adults in health research.

DEVELOPING /EXPANDING COMMUNITY OUTREACH

Working with Latino and African American elderly in the community provides invaluable information about what research is needed. The specific aims of the community liaison core are to:
· Develop a centralized list of Community-Based Organizations representing Latino and African American elderly in the San Francisco Bay Area. (Current List)
· Survey these community-based organizations to identify areas of interest and priorities related to the aging of Latinos and African Americans. (1998 survey)
· Centralize a list of groups and individuals conducting research on Latinos and African American elderly.
· Facilitate communication between research institutions and Latino and African American individuals and organizations.
· Ensure the participation of the Latino and African American communities in setting a research agenda that is responsive to the needs of older Latinos and African Americans.

 

MAJOR CADC MEASUREMENT CORE PROJECTS

1. Provide Education/Training/Technical Support

  • To pilot investigators and faculty
  • Disseminate information e.g. seminars on measurement issues for faculty and pilot study investigators

2. Overview of key issues in measuring health-related quality of life in diverse populations

3. Specific measurement development and dissemination
Review SF-36 measurement studies in diverse populations

  • Develop and test measures of interpersonal processes of care for diverse patients
  • Review Spanish translations of the CES-D for adequacy of methods of translation

4. RCMAR Conference on Measurement in Year 2001

  • Lead the effort to develop a RCMAR working conference on measurement in diverse populations

An infrastructure at CADC is being developed to support the on-going participation of community-based organizations and ethnically-diverse populations in aging research to address issues of concern to African American and Latino communities. In addition, the center is establishing a community-based network to facilitate the recruitment and retention of research participants in clinical, behavioral, epidemiological and social science studies conducted by investigators affiliated with the RCARDP, as well as other researchers focused on the health of minority populations. The community liaison core develops and evaluates effective channels both locally and national to address the need to disseminate research methodologies and recruitment strategies. Dissemination of this information is an essential part of the plan to increase the participation of culturally diverse older adults in health research.

The overall aim of the measurement core is to provide training and education, resources, methodological studies, and publications on the conceptualization of health and its determinants, on measuring health and its determinants, and on methods of recruitment and retention of subjects in ways that are appropriate for minority elders. Training and education will consist of seminars and courses provided by the measurement core team, as well as mentoring of investigators as they conduct their pilot studies. Provision of resources will consist of maintaining a resource file including conceptual frameworks, measures, and methods that can be accessed by all persons affiliated with the Resource Centers for Minority Aging Research (RCMAR). Methodological studies will be varied in nature, guided or conducted by the measurement core team (e.g., tests of measures and of various recruitment methods in diverse groups). Publication and presentation of these methods at regional and national meetings and through postings on the web will be undertaken, to disseminate our measurement and methodological findings to a broad research community. The specific content aims of the measurement core are as follows:

Conceptualization of Health and Its Determinants
1. Develop theoretically strong conceptual frameworks that account for the special health and health-related issues in older, ethnically diverse populations, based on qualitative and quantitative methods.

Measurement of Health and Its Determinants
2. Identify and disseminate state-of-the-art quantitative and qualitative methods for assessing health and health-related concepts in older African-American and Latino populations.
3. Establish and disseminate guidelines for selecting measures for new studies of ethnic minority elders that will be appropriate for the study question and specific population.
4. Establish and disseminate information on methods and issues in using existing measures in diverse populations.
5. Identify and catalogue existing measures of health and its determinants, and rate measures in terms of their psychometric adequacy and suitability for use with ethnically diverse, older populations

Recruitment and Retention
6. Provide information on optimal methods of locating, recruiting, and retaining minority and low SES elders into various types of research studies, particularly in mental health studies. Summarize minimum data collection requirements for assessing the cost-effectiveness of recruitment and retention methods

With these resources and methodological work, we provide investigators from diverse disciplines with skills in developing and utilizing conceptual frameworks; selecting and testing measures; conducting necessary quantitative and qualitative studies, and recruitment skills. This should provide them with a strong methodological foundation for conducting high quality research in this important area.

Major CADC Measurement Core Projects

1. Provide Education/Training/Technical Support
To pilot investigators and faculty
Disseminate information e.g. seminars on measurement issues for faculty and pilot study investigators

2. Overview of key issues in measuring health-related quality of life in diverse populations

3. Specific measurement development and dissemination
Review SF-36 measurement studies in diverse populations
Develop and test measures of interpersonal processes of care for diverse patients
Review Spanish translations of the CES-D for adequacy of methods of translation

4. RCMAR Conference on Measurement in Year 2001
Lead the effort to develop a RCMAR working conference on measurement in diverse populations

The CADC faculty is dedicated to disseminating current information on health disparities research.  CADC faculty offer a yearly course on health disparities research methods, which covers key conceptual and methodological considerations in conducting clinical research in ethnically diverse populations. 

Along with the Multiethnic Health Equity Research Center (MERC), the CADC co-sponsors monthly seminars on recent studies conducted by findings from health disparities researchers.

The Multiethnic Health Equity Research Center (MERC) and CADC unite investigators from multiple disciplines, departments and schools in conducting clinical and outcomes research on health services, specific medical conditions, and prevention that addresses racial and ethnic disparities in health and health care.

Multiethnic Health Equity Research Center
CADC – Center for Aging in Divers Communities
UCSF, Laurel Heights Campus
3333 California Street
San Francisco 94118
Conference Room 474 and or Room 376, 3:00pm to 4:30pm

The Investigator Development Core of the CADC has three components.  First, we fund less experienced minority investigators to conduct pilot studies to investigate issues of aging in African American, Latino and Asian American populations.  These pilot studies are led or co-led by minority investigators at the junior faculty or post-doctoral fellow level and supervised by the CADC core faculty as well as affiliated aging researchers at UCSF.  We have given preference to pilot studies that focus on healthy aging, disease prevention, measurement issues, and evaluation of recruitment methods. Second, the Investigator Development Core disseminates research information to all potentially interested audiences including community-based organizations, health care professionals and trainees, and opinion leaders within the African American, Latino and Asian American communities. Third, we formalize and strengthen the Continual Mentoring Activity within CADC by engaging graduates of the program in studies and in mentoring of fellows and less experienced faculty.

Our Aims

  • To select a minimum of three studies per year both from UCSF and other local institutions to be funded for pilot work focused on the Program Themes of healthy aging, chronic disease prevention, measurement issues, or evaluation of recruitment methods.

  • To assist and mentor less experienced minority investigators funded through CADC in conducting their pilot studies and in identifying next steps in career development.

  • To disseminate research information within UCSF and more broadly regarding recommended  techniques for conducting research involving African American, Asian and Latino aging populations.

  • To sustain and expand a network of investigators with expertise in minority health and aging at UCSF.

Jason D. Flatt, PhD, MPH.
Pilot Study Title: Identifying Risk and Protective Factors for Dementia in Older Sexual and Gender Minorities (SGM).
Position: Dr. Flatt is an Assistant Professor in the Institute for Health & Aging at UCSF with a specialty in the epidemiology of dementia.
Career goal: Develop interventions to help prevent dementia among older SGM populations.
Background: Jason was the oldest son of a single mother who raised three children with limited financial and psychosocial resources. He recalls his childhood experiences of being bullied, harassed, and socially excluded due to his sexual orientation.
Why this study: SGM older adults have faced a lifetime of psychosocial risks, including marginalization, discrimination, and internalized stigma. His CADC-funded research will increase our understanding of the risk and protective factors for dementia in older SGM populations, with an ultimate goal of developing culturally adapted evidence-based interventions for these understudied interventions.
http://profiles.ucsf.edu/jason.flatt

Cathy Samayoa, PhD.
Pilot Study Title: Investigating the Effects of a Stress Management Intervention Program on Biological Markers of Stress in Latinas with Breast Cancer.
Position: Post-doctoral Fellow, Health Equity Research (HER) Laboratory, San Francisco State University.
Career goal: Develop trans-disciplinary, innovative strategies to eliminate breast cancer health disparities.
Background: As the child of immigrants with an elementary school education, her parents inculcated in Cathy the value of education as a way out of poverty. She recalls the socioeconomic and language barriers her family and community faced in all realms and their profound influence on the quality of their health and health care.
Why this study: Spanish-speaking Latinas with breast cancer are at increased risk of stress due to poverty, limited health insurance, and lack of understanding of their diagnosis and treatment. This chronic stress can “get under the skin” to cause immune dysfunction, cancer progression, and cancer recurrence.

Judy Yourong Tan, PhD, MA.
Pilot Study Title: Developing mHealth Capabilities for Healthy Aging among HIV-Positive Men who have Sex with Men of Color.
Position: Assistant Professor of Medicine, Center for AIDS Prevention Studies (CAPS), UCSF.
Career goal: Develop technology-facilitated interventions to optimize healthy aging of HIV+ MSM of color.
Background: Judy relates that growing up as a first-generation college graduate from a poor immigrant neighborhood and ethnic enclave instilled in her a passion for working on health interventions and disease prevention.
Why this study: The population of HIV+ individuals achieving viral suppression on antiretroviral therapy (ART) is growing, aging, and experiencing a widening spectrum of diseases and conditions that compromise successful aging. Mobile technology is a tremendously promising tool for integrating access to care and social support that transcends social and structural barriers.
http://profiles.ucsf.edu/judy.tan

Maria Ventura, PhD.
Pilot Study Title: Reducing Disparities in Access to Dance Therapy for Diverse Populations Diagnosed with Parkinson’s Disease.
Position: Post-Doctoral Fellow, UCSF; her research goals are to develop interventions that are effective in treating complex neurodegenerative disorders such as Parkinson’s disease (PD) and to make alternative treatment options such as dance accessible to underserved communities. Maria has studied cognitive dysfunction in different clinical populations and healthy adults using neuroimaging techniques, neuropsychological methods and behavioral rehabilitation interventions. With her background in Psychology and specialized training in Cognitive Neuroscience and Geriatrics, she believes she has laid the groundwork and has the motivation necessary to successfully carry out the proposed research.
Career goal: Develop arts-based movement interventions for diverse older individuals living with neurodegenerative diseases that will improve their daily functioning and quality of life.
Background: As the first in her family to attend an American university, Maria recalls both of her parents working multiple jobs in order to send her to school. As a Filipina woman, she was discouraged to pursue an advanced science degree and lacked role models early in her career.
Why this study: Parkinson’s disease (PD) affects motor, cognitive and emotional abilities and can have a substantial impact on daily functioning and quality of life. PD affects as many as 1 million older Americans and currently there is no cure. Costly medications or invasive surgery are only partially effective in managing symptoms, and there are significant racial/ethnic disparities with regard to PD treatment and quality of care.

2016 Request for Applications for Pilot Study Grant
Center for Aging in Diverse Communities Scholars Program

 

Background: The UCSF Center for Aging in Diverse Communities (CADC) was established in 1997 with funding from the National Institute on Aging (NIA) as part of the Resource Centers for Minority Aging Research (RCMAR) program and re-funded in 2002, 2007 and 2012. CADC’s aims are to enhance aging research in minority populations and increase involvement of minority investigators in research. The ultimate goal of CADC is to reduce persistent health disparities observed by race/ethnicity and social class among older people. Although the emphasis of CADC is on later life, aging is a life-long process and many potentially modifiable factors bearing on aging processes are linked to early or mid-life. Therefore, we interpret aging research broadly. CADC is now requesting applications for CADC Scholars who will conduct pilot studies to investigate issues of health and aging among older African American, Latino, Asian American, and Pacific Islander populations, including those who are sexual and gender minorities. CADC will fund at least three Scholars with an anticipated start date of July 1, 2016 (pending CHR approval). We are committed to mentoring CADC Scholars during and following the pilot study to support development of a successful research career. The main indicator of success will be the individual’s research career development as measured by publication of pilot study results, other publications related to aging and health disparities, and other grant applications and funding.


General Provisions: CADC Scholars will have the opportunity to interact with CADC faculty and enhance their skills and knowledge related to aging and disparities research among minority populations. Scholars will be assisted in developing and submitting a career-development or independent research proposal based their pilot study results. CADC scholars will receive training on issues pertaining to minority aging research and feedback on manuscripts, grant proposals, and other academic products through monthly works-in-progress sessions with CADC faculty and fellow CADC Scholars. They will be encouraged to participate in training opportunities offered by the National Institute on Aging. CADC Scholars will have access to the resource cores of the UCSF CADC and Older Americans Independence Center (OAIC) that supports research on the determinants of outcomes of disability in vulnerable elders. The OAIC will co-fund one of the CADC pilot awards focused on vulnerable older adults. CADC scholars are required to attend monthly meetings with other scholars and mentors.

Eligibility: The applicant must be at the assistant professor level or a postdoctoral fellow. The CADC Scholar will be Principal Investigator (PI) of the pilot study and must be from a racial/ethnic minority group as defined by self-identification or from a socioeconomically disadvantaged background of any race/ethnicity as defined by NIH. Applicants must not have received a previous independent research award of the R01 type from the NIH or similar funding agencies. Investigators who have received previous funding from faculty development awards (e.g., K awards) are eligible. Assistant professors or postdoctoral fellows located in any academic or research non-profit institutions in the San Francisco Bay Area are eligible. We will consider applications from previously funded CADC Scholars but will give preference to new applicants. Proposed pilot studies may be analyses of secondary data sets or primary data collection. We will give preference to proposals in the following CADC priority areas:
(1) Health promotion and healthy aging topics;
(2) Research projects with older minorities that engage community-based organizations;
(3) Development of measurement instruments or protocols applicable to minority groups;
(4) Cognitive function among minority older adults;
(5) Studies of aging and the arts (e.g., music, dance, art);
(6) Proposals using secondary data that include minority participants and are focused on aging;
(7) Studies on the health and well-being of ethnically diverse informal caregivers;
(8) Studies on the determinants, outcomes, and palliation of disability in older minority persons.


Application Procedures: An application (single spaced, 1-inch margins, and in Arial 11 font) must include the following:

1) Cover Page: Include name, current position, institution, mailing address, telephone number, email address, and study title

2) Research Plan: using the following required format and page limits (5 pages maximum excluding references):

a) Specific Aims, Significance, and Innovation (1 page)

b) Preliminary Studies that pertain to the application and Personal Statement and Career Goals (1 page total): Include a summary of your background, preparation for research, and career objectives total. Please include your racial/ethnic or socioeconomically disadvantaged background in the personal statement.

c) Research Methods (3 pages): Include a discussion of research design and specific research questions, setting, participants and sources of participants, recruitment methods, measures/variables to be used, sample size calculation, and analytic plan. Include at least one paragraph on expected findings and implications of your study.


3) Current full curriculum vitae

4) One-year budget not to exceed $20,000 and a budget justification using NIH forms: These budgets will need to be approved by NIA if selected for funding. Expenses may include salary and fringe benefits for the PI and research staff, research supplies, and participant payments. If you are located outside UCSF, please note that we are not able to pay any institutional indirect costs on these pilot study grants; this is a condition of award. Please note that we will not enter into a subcontract with other institutions in order to fund pilot studies if this involves indirect costs.

5) NIH biosketch and Other Support of your main research mentor

The completed electronic original application should be received no later than 5 PM on Monday, April 18, 2016, and sent to: Anna Nápoles, PhD, MPH at anapoles@ucsf.edu with a copy to Cecilia Populus-Eudave at cecilia.populus-eudave@ucsf.edu. No hard copies will be accepted.


Review Criteria: Pilot study proposals will receive priority scores based on the written reviews and a discussion by the CADC faculty. Selection of awards will be on the basis of the following criteria:

1) Potential for applicant to develop as an independent investigator and viability for the pilot study developing into an independent research proposal within two years after completion
2) Relevance to minority aging research in epidemiological, clinical, social, behavioral, translational, or implementation topics
3) Feasibility of conducting the study in one year with funds allocated
4) Scientific strength of the design, methods, and analytic plans
5) Diversity in representation of disciplines conducting aging research within UCSF or affiliated institutions

Funding: Funding decisions will be made by May 13, 2016.

Inquiries: Potential applicants may email Dr. Nápoles with programmatic questions at anapoles@ucsf.edu. For general information or questions regarding the application process or this RFA, contact: Cecilia Populus-Eudave at cecilia.populus-eudave@ucsf.edu, Center for Aging in Diverse Communities, Tel: (415) 502-4088.

We highlight some of our CADC Success Stories:


Rosa Maria Sternberg, RN, PhD, is an Assistant Professor in the UCSF Department of Family Health Care Nursing. Dr. Sternberg's prior work is highlighted in: The Science of Caring, a publication from UCSF’s School of Nursing. Learn about “transnational mothers,” undocumented Latina immigrants that come to the United States to work in low-wage jobs. Their experiences, which include dangerous US-Mexico border crossings, form a dark and under-reported chapter in America’s contemporary immigration narrative. Read about this important research here. Her CADC work has focused on the development and validation of the Stress of Immigration Scale, a multidimensional scale to assess stressors associated with immigrant status, and development of a promotore-delivered stress management intervention to reduce psychosocial distress among Latino immigrants. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26605954 .

Laura Fejerman, PhD, is an Associate Professor in the UCSF Division of General Internal Medicine, Department of Medicine. Dr. Fejerman’s research identified novel genetic variants that are associated with better survival among women with breast cancer who have a strong indigenous American ancestry. She recently received ann R01 award from NCI to study the biological mechanisms that might explain these findings. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24177181.
Yoshimi Fukuoka, RN, PhD, FAAN, is a Professor of Physiological Nursing at the UCSF School of Nursing. She was a 2009 – 2010 CADC scholar who completed a project entitled, “Tailoring a mobile phone based physical activity intervention to overweight/obese ethnic/minority women using mixed methods” Later that year, she received a K award to further her work entitled, “Cell Phone Based Physical Activity Program In Sedentary Women And Men.” Soon thereafter, Dr. Fukuoka received an R01 for her study: “Applying Mobile-Persuasive Technologies to Increase Physical Activity in Women.”
Alka Kanaya, MD, is a Professor in the UCSF Division of General Internal Medicine, Department of Medicine. She was a 2005 – 2006 CADC scholar who completed a project entitled, “Measuring Acculturation and Diet among Older South Asians: Focus Group for the CHAAT Study.” Soon after, Dr. Kanaya received a K award and an R21 to further explore the work she began as a CADC scholar. Dr. Kanaya currently has multiple R01s focused on patient-oriented translational clinical research with a focus in obesity, type 2 diabetes, and the metabolic syndrome among older South Asian adults.

The Center for Aging in Diverse Communities

Purpose.
CADC at UCSF, established with a grant from the National Institute of Aging, the National Institute of Nursing Research, and the Office of Research in Minority Health, is a resource center for African American and Latino research. The U.C.S.F. center is one of six in the country, creating a national link to resources and research opportunities. Our purpose is to decrease racial disparities in health by focusing on research in disease prevention, health promotion, and disability prevention for African American and Latino elderly.

Who We Are.
The staff is comprised of Physicians and social scientist committed to improving the health and life of ethnic women and men . Director Eliseo J. Perez-Stable M.D. and Co-director Anita Stewart Ph.D. are also on the governing council with Eugene Washington M.D., Ms.C., Gaylene Becker Ph.D., Mark Alexander Ph.D., and Anna Nápoles-Springer M.P.H.
Solutions
Research
The Center for Aging in Diverse Communities is committed to increasing research focused on the concerns of aging Latinos and African Americans by:
  • Funding and implementing new pilot studies that advance knowledge on aging in African Americans and Latinos.
  • Increasing the number of researchers devoted to improving the health of Latino and African American elderly.
  • Mentoring minority researchers by offering support for proposals, pilot studies, and dissemination of research findings.
  • Developing minority faculty with research skills and experience in Latino and African American health care.
  • Collecting and validating existing measures for research with Latinos and African Americans, and developing new measures.
  • Recruiting and retaining Latinos and African Americans for appropriate research projects.

Community Outreach
Working with Latino and African- American elderly in the community will provide invaluable information about what research is needed. Our aims are to:

  • Develop a centralized list of Community-Based Organizations representing Latino and African American elderly in the San Francisco Bay Area.
  • Survey these community-based organizations to identify areas of interest and priorities related to the aging of Latinos and African Americans.
Completed
Key Findings Available
  • Centralize a list of groups and individuals conducting research on Latinos and African- American elderly.Facilitate communication between research institutions and Latino and African-American individuals and organizations.
  • Ensure the participation of the Latino and African-American communities in setting a research agenda that is responsive to the needs of older Latinos and African Americans.
The Problem

Increased Morbidity among Latinos and African Americans.
Approximately 22% of California's over-65 population are ethnic minorities. There is evidence that African Americans and Latinos, including the elderly, suffer a disproportionate burden of disease. For instance, hypertension is more prevalent in elderly African Americans compared with Whites, and diabetes is more prevalent among African American and Latinos. Not surprisingly, a greater percentage of elderly African Americans and Latinos rate their health as fair to poor compared with Whites.
Increased Mortality among Latinos and African Americans.
African Americans have alarmingly high mortality rates. The overall age-adjusted mortality is 64% higher for African Americans than for Whites. Latinos also have higher age-adjusted mortality rates for many disorders including diabetes, renal failure, and cervical cancer.
Insufficient research for African Americans and Latinos.
Despite these statistics and the National Institute of health mandate include more minorities in research, relatively little research has been conducted on the health status and concerns of aging African Americans and Latinos.

The Center for Aging in Diverse Communities

Purpose.
CADC at UCSF, established with a grant from the National Institute of Aging, the National Institute of Nursing Research, and the Office of Research in Minority Health, is a resource center for African American and Latino research. The U.C.S.F. center is one of six in the country, creating a national link to resources and research opportunities. Our purpose is to decrease racial disparities in health by focusing on research in disease prevention, health promotion, and disability prevention for African American and Latino elderly.

Who We Are.
The staff is comprised of Physicians and social scientist committed to improving the health and life of ethnic women and men . Director Eliseo J. Perez-Stable M.D. and Co-director Anita Stewart Ph.D. are also on the governing council with Eugene Washington M.D., Ms.C., Gaylene Becker Ph.D., Mark Alexander Ph.D., and Anna Nápoles-Springer M.P.H.
Solutions
Research
The Center for Aging in Diverse Communities is committed to increasing research focused on the concerns of aging Latinos and African Americans by:
  • Funding and implementing new pilot studies that advance knowledge on aging in African Americans and Latinos.
  • Increasing the number of researchers devoted to improving the health of Latino and African American elderly.
  • Mentoring minority researchers by offering support for proposals, pilot studies, and dissemination of research findings.
  • Developing minority faculty with research skills and experience in Latino and African American health care.
  • Collecting and validating existing measures for research with Latinos and African Americans, and developing new measures.
  • Recruiting and retaining Latinos and African Americans for appropriate research projects.

Community Outreach
Working with Latino and African- American elderly in the community will provide invaluable information about what research is needed. Our aims are to:

  • Develop a centralized list of Community-Based Organizations representing Latino and African American elderly in the San Francisco Bay Area.
  • Survey these community-based organizations to identify areas of interest and priorities related to the aging of Latinos and African Americans.
Completed
Key Findings Available
  • Centralize a list of groups and individuals conducting research on Latinos and African- American elderly.Facilitate communication between research institutions and Latino and African-American individuals and organizations.
  • Ensure the participation of the Latino and African-American communities in setting a research agenda that is responsive to the needs of older Latinos and African Americans.
The Problem

Increased Morbidity among Latinos and African Americans.
Approximately 22% of California's over-65 population are ethnic minorities. There is evidence that African Americans and Latinos, including the elderly, suffer a disproportionate burden of disease. For instance, hypertension is more prevalent in elderly African Americans compared with Whites, and diabetes is more prevalent among African American and Latinos. Not surprisingly, a greater percentage of elderly African Americans and Latinos rate their health as fair to poor compared with Whites.
Increased Mortality among Latinos and African Americans.
African Americans have alarmingly high mortality rates. The overall age-adjusted mortality is 64% higher for African Americans than for Whites. Latinos also have higher age-adjusted mortality rates for many disorders including diabetes, renal failure, and cervical cancer.
Insufficient research for African Americans and Latinos.
Despite these statistics and the National Institute of health mandate include more minorities in research, relatively little research has been conducted on the health status and concerns of aging African Americans and Latinos.

Resource Centers for Minority Aging Research

Events

 

Survey

The mission of the Center is to decrease ethnic and racial disparities in health by focusing attention on healthy aging among older minority populations.


The Center addresses this mission by serving as a catalyst for investigators conducting research that focuses on African American, Latino and Asian elderly. We provide funding for new pilot studies and mentor minority researchers, thereby increasing the number of researchers dedicated to improving the health of diverse older adults. We also focus on improving research methods and measures for diverse populations, as well as on the recruitment and retention of minorities in research projects.

The Center participates in community outreach and continues to sustain and expand its partnerships with diverse communities of color in the San Francisco Bay Area, working to achieve mutual trust and respect between community-based organizations and UCSF. We collaborate with community-based organizations to identify areas of interest and priorities, facilitate communication between research institutions, individuals and organizations and thus ensure that our research is responsive to the needs of older minority individuals.

The Center is composed of four separate but integrated units: Administrative Core, Investigator Development Core, Measurement Core, and Community Liaison Core.

Methods for Translating/Adapting Behavioral Interventions for Diverse Groups:
A Joint Effort with the Community Liaison Core


Goal: Advance and disseminate methods for conducting community-based behavioral interventions to reduce health disparities in older minority adults.

Rationale

Translating and adapting evidence-based behavioral interventions (EBIs) into community settings to reach disparity populations can help reduce disparities.  However, conceptual models of the translation processes were not designed with disparity communities in mind, thus no methodological guidelines exist for investigators.  We provide several resources for translating EBIs specifically for disparity populations. 

Conceptual framework of process of adapting and implementing interventions –describes methodological phases in translating, adapting, and implementing interventions in disparity communities.  We outline specific methodological steps for each phase, including examples from research with ethnic minority, low-SES, and disabled populations.

  • Nápoles AM, Santoyo-Olsson J, and Stewart AL.  Methods for translating evidence-based behavioral interventions for health disparity communities.  Preventing Chronic Disease, 2013 Nov 21;10:E193. PMCID: PMC3839588.

  • Methodological Resources for Translating Evidence-Based Behavioral Interventions in Ethnically Diverse Communities: Methodological Resources
      • Summarizes key publications that include guidelines and models for translating evidence-based behavioral interventions to reach disparity populations in community settings as well as examples.
  • Behavioral interventions designed by our CADC faculty applying our translational methods
      • We provide resources from our application of translational methods to three interventions delivered in community settings to reduce health disparities.

CHAMPS

CHAMPS was developed and evaluated in a mainstream population of older adults.  After a demonstration project (CHAMPS I), CHAMPS II was evaluated using a randomized controlled trial in a Medicare HMO setting.  It successfully increased physical activity, becoming the first evidence-based intervention of this type.  A paper describing the program and outcomes of the RCT is available:

  • Stewart AL, Verboncoeur CJ, McLellan BY, Gillis DE, Rush S, Mills K, King AC, Ritter P, Brown B, Bortz WM.  Physical activity outcomes of CHAMPS II: A physical activity promotion program for older adults. Journal of Gerontologyl: A Biological Science Medical Science 2001:56;465-70. PMCID: PMC1780022

A detailed program manual for CHAMPS II is available on the CHAMPS website

CHAMPS II has been reviewed by the Research Tested Interventions Programs (RTIPS) site.

CHAMPS III is the first application of this evidence-based program in real-world settings.  Translational research methods were used to adapt it to reach low-income primarily African American and Latino communities.  The translational process involved working with staff and community members at three community-based settings to adapt CHAMPS to accommodate sites' limited resources, and to be culturally appropriate and sustainable.  A paper describing the process is available:

  • Stewart AL, Gillis D, Grossman M, Castrillo M, Pruitt L, McLellan B, et al. Diffusing a research-based physical activity promotion program for seniors into diverse communities: CHAMPS III. Preventing Chronic Disease. 2006;3(2):A51. PMCID: PMC1563966.
  • Always Active (Siempre Activo) is the specific CHAMPS III program offered at On Lok’s 30th Street Senior Center.  That program (delivered in English and Spanish) was sustained through their efforts and expanded to nine senior centers in San Francisco.  This is an example of further translation and dissemination into local community settings.

Live Well, Be Well

The Live Well, Be Well intervention is adapted from evidence-based interventions and designed for delivery in Spanish and English by trained counselors in community settings.  It provides education and skills training to improve diet and increase physical activity.  It includes diabetes health education and risk screening.  Resources include three publications and a detailed program manual.

Program description and methods of translating evidence into this program:

  • Delgadillo AT, Grossman M, Santoyo-Olsson J, Gallegos-Jackson E, Kanaya AM, Stewart AL. Description of an academic community partnership lifestyle program for lower income minority adults at risk for diabetes. The Diabetes Educator. 2010;36(4):640-50. PMCID: PMC3771540.

For study recruitment, we used a unique community-based two-phased approach: 1: Community-based outreach and diabetes screening to provide health education about risk factors and personal risk, 2: Those at risk were recruited into the study.  A paper describes this recruitment strategy.

  • Santoyo-Olsson J, Cabrera J, Freyre R, Grossman M, Alvarez N, Mathur D, Guerrero M, Delgadillo AT, Kanaya AM, and Stewart AL. An innovative multiphased strategy to recruit underserved adults into a randomized trial of a community-based diabetes risk reduction program. Gerontologist 2011;51 Suppl 1:S82-93.  PMCID: PMC3092977.

Outcomes of the randomized controlled trial are published:

  • Kanaya AM, Santoyo-Olsson J, Gregorich S, Grossman M, Moore T, Stewart AL. The Live Well, Be Well study: a community-based, translational lifestyle program to lower diabetes risk factors in ethnic minority and lower-socioeconomic status adults. Am J Public Health. 2012 Aug;102(8):1551-8. PMCID: PMC3395772.

The Live Well, Be Well website includes:

  • Materials and procedures for community-based outreach and diabetes screening including a brief low-literacy Diabetes Risk Assessment tool for quick assessment;
  • Step-by-step procedures and resources for implementing the program;
  • Participant program binder in Spanish and English (appropriate for low-literacy groups).

Nuevo Amanecer

Nuevo Amanecer is a culturally tailored, peer-delivered cognitive-behavioral stress-management intervention for low-income Spanish-speaking Latinas with breast cancer.  It was developed according to the CADC translational processes model cited above.  Three publications are available, as follows:

1. Nápoles-Springer AM, Ortiz C, O’Brien H, Diaz-Mendez M.  Developing a culturally competent peer support intervention for Spanish-speaking Latinas with breast cancer. Journal of Immigrant and Minority Health, 2009;11(4):268-80. Epub 2008 Mar 14. PMC3832434.

Describes the processes of conducting formative research to identify barriers and facilitators to providing an effective peer-support counselor intervention for Latinas with breast cancer.  Qualitative interviews were conducted with Latina cancer patients and advocates. 

2. Nápoles AM, Santoyo-Olsson J, Ortiz C, Gregorich S, Lee HE, Duron Y, Graves K, Luce JA, McGuire P, Díaz-Méndez M, Stewart AL.  Randomized controlled trial of Nuevo Amanecer: A peer-delivered stress management intervention for Spanish-speaking Latinas with breast cancer. Clinical Trials, 2014;11(2):230-8. Epub 2014 Feb 26. PMC3972263.

The processes used to develop the 8-week Nuevo Amanecer intervention are described in detail, with step-by-step application of the translational processes model.  Community-based participatory research methods were used to integrate an evidence-based intervention tested in white breast cancer patients, a community best-practices intervention for Latinas with breast cancer, formative research, and literature.  Community capacity was built to deliver the program in community settings using peers (Latinas who had completed treatment for breast cancer).  The program was implemented and evaluated in a randomized, controlled trial.

3. Nápoles AM, Ortiz C, Santoyo-Olsson J, Stewart AL, Gregorich S, Lee HE, Duron Y, McGuire P, Luce J. Nuevo Amanecer: Results of a RCT of a Community-based, Peer-delivered Stress Management Intervention to Improve Quality of Life in Latinas with Breast Cancer. American Journal of Public Health, 2015 June; 105 (6s). PMC4455521.

This paper presents the results of the 6-month randomized controlled trial of the Nuevo Amanecer program.  The study had 95% retention at 6 months, and improvements in several measures of quality of life were observed including physical well-being, emotional well-being, breast cancer concerns, and overall quality of life.  Decreases were observed in depression and somatization.  Results suggested that translational methods can result in effective interventions for disparity populations.

Behavioral Interventions by CADC Faculty

 

Three behavioral interventions have been implemented by our teams: 

  1. CHAMPS (Community Healthy Activities Model Program for Seniors) is a series of interventions to increase physical activity levels of seniors based on evidence that increasing physical activity improves health and well-being.  The programs encourage participants to increase physical activity based on their readiness, preferences, health, and abilities.  We provide publications and program manuals for CHAMPS.  READ MORE

  2. Live Well, Be Well – Risk of diabetes is greater for most ethnic minority and lower socioeconomic status groups.  Although evidence-based interventions are available, few were designed for minority groups or delivery in community settings.  Live Well, Be Well is a lifestyle intervention to reduce risk of diabetes for lower SES, minority, Spanish-speaking, and low literacy populations.  We provide publications and program manuals.  READ MORE

  3. Nuevo Amanecer – This is a culturally tailored, peer-delivered cognitive-behavioral stress-management intervention for low-income Spanish-speaking Latinas with breast cancer.  We provide publications describing the processes of development and translation. READ MORE
