Name of Project:
Vigor2 Study (Vascular insufficiency - goals for optimal risk reduction)

Investigator(s):

PI: Roberta Oka, roberta.oka@nursing.ucsf.edu
Primary contact: Dennis Keane, dkeane@thecenter.ucsf.edu

Research question(s):

Effect of multiple risk factor reduction (MRF) program utilizing a chronic care delivery system focused on behavior change, consisting of planned visits, clinical decision support suing current treatment guidelines and follow-up delivered by nurse and dietitian case managers, versus enhanced standard care on walking distance and endothelial function.

Brief background/Significance:

People with PAD are at increased risk for death and disability because of severe atherosclerosis resulting from untreated CVD risk factors. This study will contribute to the overall mission of NINR and to nursing science by providing the necessary evidence for the efficacy of a commonly utilized nursing intervention, multiple risk factor reduction, on improving physical function and quality of life in the understudied, elderly PAD patient. This application will also provide preliminary evidence for the biological basis for the efficacy of multifactor risk reduction in restoring vascular homeostasis, critical because of its role in antiatherogenesis and maintaining vasoreactivity, both necessary for slowing the progression of atherosclerosis.

This study will examine the effect of a system that assists providers to reduce a patient's CVD risk factors and explores the biological reasons that this system may be effective in improving health.

Inclusion/Exclusion criteria:

Inclusion:

Age >40
Diagnosis of PAD
Low ankle-brachial index(ABI)

Exclusion:

Current cancer treatment
Surgery within last 90 days
Assistive walking device necessary
Able to walk > 15 minutes w/o
claudication
Unable to walk two minutes

Method of contact/recruitment:

  1. Direct mailing to seniors in San Francisco
  2. Brochures/flyers will be posted in pharmacies, senior centers, clinics, supermarkets, etc.
  3. Physician referral

Respondents calling the listed study number will be screened over the telephone and invited to an orientation to learn more about the study and requirements of participation.

Benefits/burden for participants:

Both treatment and control groups will receive extensive lab testing at no cost. Both cohorts will be able to utilize the study website that contains advice/information and links to resources on diet, exercise, smoking cessation and stress management. The treatment group will receive the benefit of a case manager to assist in lifestyle changes.

The potential risks involved in this project include: 1) medical complications resulting from evaluation procedures; 2) psychological complications resulting from the evaluation procedures; 3) potential adverse events associated with more intensive risk management; 4) potential inconvenience caused by study visits and phone calls; 5) the potential for breach of confidentiality. Many of these risks apply to both treatment and control cohorts.

Any benefits or burdens to DGIM practitioners:

Added support for patients to make lifestyle changes could be a real benefit to practitioners.

Timeline for recruitment (projected start and stop dates):

Recruitment will begin approximately May 20, 2007 and continue through May 2009.

Funding source:

National Institutes of Health

Potential for DGIM collaborators:

Collaboration is welcomed. We have discussed a sub-study of the efficacy of recruitment strategies in diverse communities with Dr. Moreno-John.

Do you agree to notify us when recruitment is completed?

Yes.

Date form completed
May 15, 2007

Name of Project:
Compositional Breast Density as a Risk Factor

Investigator(s):
John A. Shepherd, PI
john.shepherd@radiology.ucsf.edu

Karla Kerlikowske, Co-PI
kerliko@itsa.ucsf.edu

Jessie Landau, Study Coordinator (primary contact)
jessie.landau@radiology.ucsf.edu

Research question(s):

  • To further develop and validate a method to measure tissue composition using single x-ray absorptiometry (SXA) techniques using standard mammogram x-ray protocols against known standards of compositional density (DXA and phantoms).
  • To develop and characterize a new method of measuring breast tissue composition using bioimpedance analysis (BIA). The method is designed to measure breast density as percentage fat at the time of standard film screen mammography without user intervention or the viewing of an image.
  • To quantify the precision of the bioimpedance technique in vivo.
  • To gather preliminary data to determine whether women with a greater proportion of compositionally dense breast tissue are at greater risk of breast cancer than women with less compositionally dense breasts controlling for known risk factors.
  • To determine the correlation between breast compositional density methods and mammographic density.
  • To quantify the repeatability in measuring breast tissue composition using either the SXA, DXA, bioimpedance, or the more conventional mammographic density methodology.

Brief Background/Significance:
Mammographic breast density is one of the strongest predictors of breast cancer risk. Women with greater than 50% of total breast area that is mammographically dense are at 3 to 5 fold greater risk of breast cancer than women with less than 25% mammographically dense breasts. The prevalence of mammographically dense breasts is high among breast cancer cases with 42% of cases with 50% or more mammographically dense breasts compared with 32% of those without breast cancer (OR= 3.1).

Mammographic density is quantified as a continuous grading from 0 t 100% density and defined by delineating the radiographically dense areas in the mammogram from the entire breast area and providing a percentage breast density (PD) defined as PD = (high radiographic density area)/(total breast area). Although this method has shown to be a strong risk factor, it is neither precise nor accurate enough to be used to monitor the risk of individual women.

As an alternative, we propose to measure the breast tissue on a pixel-by-pixel basis and report a percentage fat and dense mass. An SXA reference phantom has been designed for this project. The phantom provides a measure of tissue composition at the two extremes of the tissue composition scale. The phantom is placed on the upper edge of the mammogram field such that it does not interfere with the projection of the breast tissue. It is constructed of two polymers that is necessary for the measurement. Dr. Edward Sickles, MD, Chief of Breast Imaging at UCSF has agreed to allow the use of the phantom on mammography units when obtaining standard clinical films.

We will also measure breast density by taking low radiation x-ray scans of breasts on a device called a dual x-ray absorptiometer (DXA). Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DXA) body composition measurements are the gold standard for whole body and subregional compositional measurements. The final method we will use to measure breast compositional density is through bioimpedance analysis. Bioimpedance Analysis (BIA) is safe, provides clinically useful estimates of tissue composition in both healthy and disease populations, and has been shown to be valid for subregional tissue assessment.

Breast compositional density could be used as a marker to predict breast cancer risk and possibly risk of disease recurrence or change in breast cancer risk. For example, promising interventions that may decrease breast cancer risk such as a low fat diet, (12,13) phytoestrogens or hormone manipulations (14,15) could be first tested by examining whether the proportion of breast area with mammographic densities is affected by the intervention prior to conducting a large randomized controlled trial that determines the influence on breast cancer incidence. In addition, breast compositional density could be used to identify women at sufficient risk to warrant treatment with SERMS or new agents for prevention of breast cancer. Breast densitometry could provide a new tool for clinical and basic scientists to better understand how proliferated breast stroma (mammographic breast densities) may interact with breast epithelium to promote growth of breast tumor cells. Results of this preliminary comparison will be used to consider and plan prospective and case-control studies to determine the relation of breast tissue composition to breast cancer risk.

Inclusion/exclusion criteria (list)

Inclusion:
Post-Menopausal Women

Exclusion:
Women who have undergone a mastectomy or have breast implants will be excluded.

Method of contact/recruitment

We will be recruiting postmenopausal women with unilateral breast cancer (cases) and women without breast cancer (controls). Cases: The UCSF Carol Frank Buck Center presents each woman diagnosed with breast cancer a "Surgical Trials Overview". The nurse or physician reviews this document with the patient. The nurse marks which trials the patient is eligible for and then the patient marks if it is OK to contact them regarding each particular study. If a patient marks that it is OK to be contacted for our study, we will call the subject, describe the study in more detail, answer their questions, and go through the inclusion/exclusion criteria. If a woman is interested she may also be given the "Woman to Woman" letter written by the UCSF breast cancer advocates. See the "Woman to Woman" letter in the attached documents.

Controls: The controls will be picked randomly from the SFMR database that are age-match to the cases, within 8 months of their next mammogram, and that had checked the "OK to contact" box on the SFMR questionnaire. These patients will be mailed a letter describing the study and then be called 1 week later to inquire about their interest in the study, describe the study in more detail, answer their questions, and go through the inclusion/exclusion criteria.

Advertisements will also be placed in and around physician's offices for recruitment purposes. Please see the advertisement in the attached documents.

Benefits/burden for participants The use of the phantom during standard clinical mammograms does not impact adversely on patient care in any way. The amount of radiation the patient will be exposed to for the study is relatively small. Such doses of radiation may be potentially harmful, but the risks are so small that they are difficult to measure. The amount of additional radiation received from the study protocol beyond the clinical mammograms is less than the average monthly dose an individual receives from naturally occurring background radiation when living in San Francisco. This dose is also comparable to taking 4 roundtrip plane trips from San Francisco to New York.

The bioimpedance measurement is commonly used to measure body fat and is even available to consumers in bathroom scales. The electrical current used is so small that the participant cannot detect it and no harmful effects have ever been reported. Participation in the study may result in some loss of privacy; however, we will protect confidentiality as much as possible. Individual results will not be reported.

Any benefits or burden to DGIM practitioners?
While there are no direct benefits to DGIM practitioners, it is hoped that determining an accurate and precise way to quantify breast density in individual women will allow practitioners to better identify patients at risk for breast cancer.

Timeline for recruitment (projected start and stop dates)
This project has been ongoing since March 2003.

Funding source
CA Breast Cancer Research Program

Potential for DGIM collaborators?
Dr. Kerlikowske is part of the Department of General Internal Medicine.

Here is an update on some of the issues that are occupying my attention as your interim Division Chief. As always, please let me know if you would like to meet with me to discuss these or anything else that is on your mind. I am available during ‘office hours’ on Wed or please e-mail Ria Melendres to schedule an appointment.

The budget and incentives. There is mostly good news for FY15 (yes--we and the rest of the DOM are still working on last year's numbers.) First the good news; thanks to our outstanding clinical productivity, we ended FY15 with a small surplus and will be able to pay clinical incentives. All faculty clinicians will receive a $1500 bonus tied to participation in QI activities. In addition, clinical faculty who exceeded their RVU goals will receive an additional incentive that will be paid at about $45 per RVU. About 2/3 of faculty exceeded their goals and will receive an incentive payment. I will send you an individual e-mail in December with your numbers and would be happy to discuss in person.

Unfortunately, per our agreement with the DOM for FY15, since our surplus is less than $100,000, there is no mechanism by which to pay PhD faculty an incentive payment this year. We proposed a different methodology for FY16 and I expect that all DGIM faculty will be able to participate next year. This is in keeping with our philosophy of shared responsibility and shared recognition in DGIM. I expect that we will end FY16 in a better position than last year, but as the division, the DOM and UC Health are all still adjusting to the new funds flow model, it has become more difficult to make dependable projections. What is still true however is that we will be better off if we finish the year having met our RVU goals—so I greatly appreciate your hard work and dedication to patient care.

Other issues that we have been discussing in the Executive Committee include Recruitment. We are pleased that Veronica Yank, MD will be joining us in December; please remember to give her a warm welcome when you see her. Veronica will see patients and precept at 1545 and will be located at Laurel Hts for her research. Lei Choi, MD will be joining us in January. Lei was hired by UC Health to help lead the LEAN initiatives on campus and is also a dedicated primary care doctor. She will join the 1701 practice and also precept. We are fortunate to have Lei join the division to educate us on LEAN and help us to improve our clinical processes. We are interviewing other candidates for both clinician investigator and clinician educator faculty positions and I hope to be able to announce other new hires soon.

And speaking of improvement in clinical process, I am grateful to the faculty and staff (Don Ng, Kathy Julian, Scott Steiger, Michelle Guy, Jason Selinger, Anais Ochoa, Jenny Pacholuk and Kelly McNeil) who have agreed to serve on the DGIM Clinical Practice Task Force. I have asked them to review the many excellent recommendations that came from the series of meetings chaired by Kathy in the Fall and to come up with a plan to implement as many of them as possible as soon as is feasible. In addition, they will produce recommendations that I can bring to the DOM and to leadership in UC Health for what we need to support sustainable clinical jobs in DGIM; whether it is more administrative time, more support staff, to hire clinical scribes etc. Change is needed, and I will continue to advocate for what we need to accomplish the quadruple aim of improving the work life of health care providers, including faculty and staff.

I hope to see everyone at the DGIM Faculty Meeting on December 2 and the DGIM Holiday Party on December 17. For the faculty meeting, I invite all faculty to come for breakfast and open discussion as we reflect on the year to date and discuss our priorities for the rest of the year. For the holiday party, we picked a venue that is centrally located and close to both Divisadero as well as Laurel Hts and will have it catered with delicious (and a bit more heart healthy) food and drink. Please come celebrate with your colleagues and bring your family.

I remain grateful for the opportunity to serve as your interim Chief and look forward to continuing our work together this year.

Warm regards,

Mitch

◇ New Grants in DGIM

Doug Bauer PI - NIAMS R01
Project Title: Atypical Femoral Fractures: A Population-Based Study of Risk Factors and Relationship to Bisphosphonate Exposure and Discontinuation. A comprehensive assessment of risk factors for atypical femoral fract​ures, including dose-response relationships with bisphosphonate use and time since discontinuation, using Danish National Health fracture and pharmacy data since 1995. UCSF will coordinate the study, adjudicate atypical fractures and conduct analyses with Danish collaborators.
Jane Jih PI - NIA R03 GEMSSTAR
Project Title: Identifying and Assessing Food Insecurity in Older Diverse Primary Care Patients. The study aims to describe the prevalence and associated clinical characteristics of food insecurity among a sample of diverse older adult patients with multiple chronic conditions, assess the utility of Photovoice to elicit patient beliefs and behaviors of food insecurity, and assess the feasibility, acceptability and potential impact of incorporating Photovoice as a communication and assessment tool in the primary care setting through the lens of food insecurity. This study will be conducted at the UCSF General Medicine Practice at Mt Zion. The NIA R03 GEMSSTAR will also support the career development of Jane Jih.
Celia Kaplan PI, Leah Karliner Co-I - Tobacco-Related Disease Research Program (TRDRP).
Project Title: Lung Cancer Screening: The Views of Patients and Physicians. The study will assess the barriers and facilitators of lung cancer screening among a multiethnic patient population and their primary care providers. Patient and physician perspectives will be integrated to determine the best methods and messages for communicating risk, benefits, and options for lung cancer screening
Celia Kaplan PI, Leah Karliner Co-I. Mt. Zion Health Fund.
Project Title: Access to UCSF Patient Portal: Development of a Clinic-Based Training . The purpose of the study is to improve the uptake and use of the MyChart portal among adults 65 years and older, by developing and pretesting a clinic-based training that addresses patient and physician views and incorporates clinic staff recommendations.
Leah Karliner (PI) Celia Kaplan and Steve Gregorich (CO-I). PCORI (Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute).
Project Title: Clinician Language Concordance and Interpreter Use: Impact of a Systems Intervention on Communication and Clinical Outcomes.: The study will provide information about whether a systems intervention can increase appropriate means of communication during clinical care with LEP patients, and whether, in turn, that improvement will have a positive impact on communication and clinical outcomes
Anna Napoles, PI; Carmen Ortiz Co-PI. California Breast Cancer Research Program Translational Research Award.
Project Title: Translating a Stress Management Program for Latinas. Our objectives are to create a transportable Nuevo Amanecer cognitive-behavioral stress management program that is suitable for urban and rural Latinas of various literacy levels and test this revised program in a randomized controlled trial in new rural community settings.
Anna Napoles, PI. Susan G. Komen Investigator-initiated Research Grant.
Project Title: mHealth Cancer Fatigue Management Tool for Low-income Women on Chemotherapy. This study will evaluate the feasibility, acceptability and preliminary effectiveness of a 3-month CBSM intervention delivered via an interactive mobile phone application (mCBSM) to ethnically diverse low-SES women with breast cancer during chemotherapy treatment.

DGIM News and Notes - August 2016

◇ Message From the Chief

Venezuela’s Health Crisis: We Can Help

There is a humanitarian and health crisis in Venezuela that has been pushed off the front page but deserves our attention. This story appeared in the NY Times in May 2016 titled “Dying Infants and No Medicine: Inside Venezuela’s Failing Hospitals”, http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/16/world/americas/dying-infants-and-no-medicine-inside-venezuelas-failing-hospitals.html and the situation has only become more urgent in the past few months.

As the Times reports, the rate of death among babies under a month old increased more than a hundredfold in public hospitals in Venezuela from 2012 to 2015. The rate of death among new mothers in those hospitals increased by almost five times in the same period. The article quotes a physician who states: "There are people dying for lack of medicine, children dying of malnutrition and others dying because there are no medical personnel."

A friend and political refugee from Venezuela made me aware of this growing crisis. She is collaborating with the physician-director of a children’s hospital in Caracas called Hospital San Juan de Dios that is in dire need of pediatric medicines and supplies. They need everything but we are able to send only over-the-counter pediatric medication for now: pain and antipyretic/anti-inflammatory meds (NSAIDS, acetaminophen), allergy meds (antihistamines), OTC topical steroids and multivitamins. Gauze, syringes and other supplies are also appreciated.

I will collect these items at the DGIM faculty retreat on September 23.

Thanks for your help.

◇ Announcements

Dr. Michelle Guy Selected As New Director of Diversity for GME
Michelle Guy, MD, has been chosen to be the new Director of Diversity for GME. In this role, Dr. Guy will support diversity in our residency and fellowship programs. She will work with GME program directors to recruit and retain diverse trainees from groups traditionally underrepresented in medicine (UIM). She will also develop and implement programs to retain existing UIM residents and fellows.

Michelle will also serve on the Graduate Medical Education Committee (GMEC) and the GMEC Executive Committee and will chair the GME Diversity Advisory Group as well as serving on campus committees related to diversity and collaborating with Diversity Directors from other UCSF Schools.

Dr. Irene Yen Presents at National Academy of Sciences Workshop
Irene Yen, PhD, MPH, presented "Built Environment: What It Is and How It Influences Diets of Older Adults" at a National Academy of Sciences workshop "Meeting the Dietary Needs of Older Adults." The workshop, which was held October 28-29, 2015 at The National Academies in Washington, DC, examined factors in the physical, social, and cultural environment that affect the ability of older adults to meet their daily dietary needs. Speakers described the unique dietary needs of people age 50+ and challenges to meeting them, with a particular focus on vulnerable populations and provided an overview of strategies employed to help meet these needs.

The summary from the workshop: "Meeting the Dietary Needs of Older Adults Exploring the Impact of the Physical, Social, and Cultural Environment" was published on July 14 and is available for download here: http://www.nationalacademies.org/hmd/reports/2016/Meeting-the-Dietary-Needs-of-Older-Adults-WS

Dr. Tung Nguyen Selected as Member of PCORI Panel
Tung Nguyen, MD, has been selected to the Advisory Panel on Addressing Disparities of the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute (PCORI). Membership on the panel is for a term of 3 years. The priorities of the panel are to identify potential differences in prevention, diagnosis, or treatment effectiveness, or preferred clinical outcomes across patient populations and the healthcare required to achieve best outcomes in each population.

More information about the PCORI Advisory Panel on Addressing Disparities is available on the PCORI website

Dr. Rena Fox Interviewed for Story on NPR Website
Rena Fox, MD, was interviewed in July for a story that appeared on the NPR website's "Goats and Soda" Blog. The story "What Kills More People Each Year: TB, HIV/AIDS Or Viral Hepatitis?" discusses the findings of the "Global Burden of Disease Study 2013." The study provides an improved understanding of the burden of viral hepatitis which can inform global intervention strategies.

"Without data to understand where the problem exists and how many people we're talking about, I don't think efforts can be measured," Fox said. "Now we can spur regions and countries to start measuring their successes."

To read the story, visit the NPR website: What Kills More People Each Year: TB, HIV/AIDS Or Viral Hepatitis?

Dr. Pam Ling Elected to UCSF Academic Senate Committee on Committees
The UCSF Academic Senate Office has announced that Pam Ling, MD, has been elected to the Academic Senate Committee on Committees. There are nine members of the Committee on Committees, each serving a three-year term.

Information about the UCSF Academic Senate is available on their website: http://senate.ucsf.edu

◇ Featured Publications

Dr. Leslie Sheu and Co-authors Publish Editorial in Journal of General Internal Medicine
Drs. Leslie Sheu, Ryan Laponis, and Kathy Julian, published a commentary in the August issue of the Journal of General Internal Medicine titled, "Educating the Next Generation of Physicians in Interprofessional Collaboration." The commentary reviews an article published in the same issue of JGIM, "Charting a Key Competency Domain: Understanding Resident Physician Interprofessional Collaboration (IPC) Skills" by Sondra Zabar, et al, about assessment of interprofessional collaboration.

It is a starting point to larger conversations around the importance of interprofessional collaboration, how to best assess it, and how to design training opportunities to develop this skill. To read the two-page commentary, please visit: http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11606-016-3731-1/fulltext.html

Dr. Rena Pasick and Co-authors Publish Paper in American Journal of Public Health
Rena Pasick, DrPH, and coauthors, including Celia Kaplan and Tung Nguyen, MD, published an article in the August issue of the American Journal of Public Health.

The article "Effective Referral of Low-Income Women at Risk for Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer to Genetic Counseling: A Randomized Delayed Intervention Control Trial" is available on the AJPH website.

◇ DGIM Welcomes New Fellow

Meet Tim Anderson, Our New Primary Care Research Fellow
We are pleased to welcome Tim Anderson as a new Primary Care Research Fellow in DGIM. Prior to joining UCSF, Tim completed internal medicine residency and chief residency at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. His research focuses on understanding the system- and physician-level factors which drive variation in care delivery and clinical outcomes of patients with hypertension, diabetes and cardiovascular disease. His research interests include studying the pharmacoepidemiology of cardiovascular medications, the use of diagnostic testing in cardiovascular disease and the impact of marketing and financial relationships on prescribing behavior.

Tim ultimately aims to translate an improved understanding of the upstream factors driving variation in cardiovascular care delivery into implementing educational programs and delivery system improvements to enhance the value of the care we provide. Tim's research interests are driven by his clinical experiences as a primary care physician and resident preceptor at the Mt. Zion General Internal Medicine Clinic.

DGIM News and Notes - December 2015

◇ Message From the Chief

Best wishes for a restful and 'quiet' holiday

As the new year approaches, I am always reminded to re-read a short essay by the writer Pico Ayer that first appeared in the New York Times in 2011. In that essay titled "The Joy of Quiet," Ayer writes about how technology so dominates our lives that we have lost touch with the importance of being quiet. He writes:

"In barely one generation we’ve moved from exulting in the timesaving devices that have so expanded our lives to trying to get away from them -- often in order to make more time. The more ways we have to connect, the more many of us seem desperate to unplug. . . . We have more and more ways to communicate . . . but less and less to say."

While "digital medicine" (the theme of this year's Department of Medicine retreat) promises to improve the delivery and outcomes of health care, the ubiquity of technology in our daily lives has come at a cost both at work and at home. I need not remind you of the many ways we are all tethered to our smart phones, tablets, computers and now even our watches; all ensure that we are never more than a click or buzz away from urgent but rarely essential information.

This relentless distraction means that we rarely take the time to reflect on the values that motivate us and the people that are most important in our lives. As I once wrote:

"Well-being arises in part from the personal values that we develop and cherish, as well as the choices we make in our attempts to honor those values."

During this holiday season, I encourage you to set aside some time without your phone or computer to simply be quiet and to reflect on your values and your choices at work and at home. Some have said humorously that the mind is a dangerous place to visit—don't go there alone. But I think you should take the risk and simply be alone with your thoughts, if even for just a few hours. It may be the most difficult, and most rewarding, activity you engage in.

I want to thank everyone for a successful 2015 and wish you all a happy and healthy New Year. See you in 2016!

◇ Announcements

Women’s HIV Program at UCSF Selected to Advance Trauma-Informed Care
The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation's Center for Health Care Strategies has chosen the UCSF Women's HIV Program, directed by Eddy Machtinger, MD, to be part of the Advancing Trauma-Informed Care national initiative.

The Women’s HIV Program will receive funding support and participate in a two-year learning collaborative to vet new approaches, exchange best practices, and advance practical strategies for implementing trauma-informed care.

In addition to the Women’s HIV Program, the pilot sites include: Center for Youth Wellness (San Francisco, CA); Montefiore Health System (Bronx, NY); Greater Newark Healthcare Coalition (Newark, NJ); Stephen and Sandra Sheller 11th Street Family Health Services (Philadelphia, PA); and San Francisco Department of Public Health, (San Francisco, CA).

Over two years, the pilot sites will test and enhance key clinical and organizational ingredients for a trauma-informed approach to care, guided by input from the learning collaborative and a national advisory committee as well as technical assistance from CHCS.

To read more about the Advancing Trauma-Informed Care initiative, please visit the Center for Health Care Strategies website

Drs. Rene Salazar and Tung Nguyen Selected as Dean's Diversity Leaders
The UCSF School of Medicine is committed to developing and sustaining a culture of equity and inclusion.

The Differences Matter initiative has been launched to close gaps in health and health care. Leaders for the 6 Focus Areas in the initiative have been announced and two members of the DGIM Faculty have been selected.

Congratulations to Rene Salazar, MD, who has been named as a leader in Focus Area 1, which will "Develop an informed and committed leadership, educated to oversee a culture of inclusion and to achieve greater diversity."

Congratulations also to Tung Nguyen, MD, a leader in Focus Area 5, which will "Increase the diversity of discovery topics, clinical research and the scientific workforce to provide better insights into the health and health care needs of our increasingly diverse population."

To read more about the initiative please visit http://medschool.ucsf.edu/differences-matter

Drs. Michelle Guy and Brent Kobashi Chosen as Medical Student Coaches

 The first group of medical student coaches has been selected in the School of Medicine Bridges Curriculum. Among the 27 faculty coaches chosen are Michelle Guy and Brent Kobashi.

Applicants were selected based on their commitment to and experience in medical student education, mentoring, clinical skills instruction, professionalism, student wellbeing, diversity, and systems improvement.

Coaches will provide academic guidance for students and support their professional and personal development. The coach will be assigned a group of six first-year medical students to oversee throughout their medical school curriculum and six third-year students, starting in August 2016. They will review their students’ progress and guide students in individual learning planning. Coaches will also be prepared to refer students to the range of resources and career advisors available at UCSF.

More information about the coaches in the UCSF Bridges Curriculum can be found on the UCSF Medical Education Bridges Curriculum website.

DGIM News and Notes - January 2016

◇ Message From the Chief

Diversity and Inclusion in DGIM

As we begin a new year, one of the issues I would especially like to focus on is diversity and inclusion in DGIM. We are proud of the fact that DGIM is home to two of the newly appointed SOM Deans Diversity Leaders (Rene Salazar and Tung Nguyen) and our own Bobby Baron was recently honored for his many years of tremendous work on behalf of diversity and inclusion at UCSF (https://www.ucsf.edu/news/2016/01/401371/diversity-and-outreach-office-celebrates-5th-anniversary-honoring-founders). 

I know that many of you were able to hear Angela Byars-Winston, PhD give the Department of Medicine Grand Rounds a few weeks ago. I met Angela during a mentor training conference at University of Wisconsin and I invited her to UCSF as part of the UCSF Faculty Mentoring Program activities for National Mentoring Month. While we can be proud of our long commitment to diversity in DGIM, we cannot rest on our good intentions and past successes but must continuously strive to do better. None of us is immune to the insidious influence of unconscious bias in our interactions with patients, staff and each other. And as Dr. Byars-Winston reminded us, it is not up to those most impacted by this bias to have to always speak up, but in fact we all have the responsibility and none more than those least impacted by racism and bias. Please be sure to attend the faculty meeting in February; we will devote most of the meeting to a discussion of diversity and inclusion in DGIM. I welcome your ideas and your help. 

◇ Announcements

Dr. Stephen McPhee to Receive AAHPM National Leadership Award

In recognition for his achievements and profound influence in the field of palliative medicine, Steve McPhee, MD, will receive the American Academy of Hospital and Palliative Medicine (AAHPM) National Leadership Award during the 2016 AAHPM & Hospice & Palliative Nurses Association (HPNA) Annual Assembly to be held in Chicago, Illinois in March.

More information about the AAHPM & HPNA Annual Assembly is available at the AAHPM website.

Dr. Pamela Ling Recommended for Election to American Society for Clinical Investigation

Pamela Ling, MD, has been recommended for membership to the American Society for Clinical Investigation (ASCI). ASCI, established in 1908, is one of the nation’s oldest and most respected medical honor societies. The ASCI seeks to support the scientific efforts, educational needs, and clinical aspirations of physician-scientists to improve human health. With more than 3,000 physician-scientists, the ASCI is dedicated to the advancement of research that improves the understanding and treatment of human diseases.

Several hundred physician-scientists are nominated for election to the Society each year but only 80 new members are chosen for their significant research accomplishments. Members must be 50 years of age or younger at the time of their election, so membership reflects accomplishments by its members early in their careers.

Dr. Rena Fox Appointed to Institute for Clinical and Economic Review Panel
Rena Fox, MD, has been appointed to the California Technology Assessment Forum (CTAF) Panel by the Institute for Clinical and Economic Review (ICER).

The CTAF Panel is composed of 17 independent California-based experts who represent a broad range of backgrounds, disciplines, and perspectives. Panel members are chosen based on their expertise in reviewing and applying medical evidence in a variety of contexts and are not selected based on their specific expertise in a given clinical area.

A list of the CTAF Panel members can be viewed at California Technology Assessment Forum website.

Dr. Mai-Khanh Bui-Duy Accepted into 2016 ACLGIM LEAD Certificate Program
Mai-Khanh Bui-Duy, MD, will be enrolled into the 2016-17 program cohort of the Association of Chiefs and Leaders of General Internal Medicine LEAD scholars.

The LEAD program is designed for junior to mid-career faculty who wish to further develop their leadership skills. Training and coaching from leadership scholars and successful General Internal Medicine leaders is provided at the ACLGIM/SGIM spring meeting and continues for one year afterwards.

Dr. Bobby Baron Recognized as UCSF Diversity Leader
Bobby Baron, MD, MS, was recognized as a Diversity "Founders Champion" by UCSF's Office of Diversity and Outreach it as marked its fifth anniversary.

Bobby Baron, along with Joseph Castro, PhD, Lisa Cisneros, Angela Echiverri, MD, MPH, Uchenna Okoye, MD, MPH, and Sharon Youmans, PharmD, MPH were honored as champions whose collective efforts focusing on diversity led to the creation of the Office of Diversity and Outreach.

To read more about the Diversity "Founders Champions" please visit the UCSF News Center

◇ DGIM Transitions

Kelly McNeill to Become Division Manager of Hematology/Oncology

Kelly McNeill has accepted the position of Division Manager with the Division of Hematology/Oncology in the UCSF Department of Medicine and will be stepping down from her position in DGIM by the end of March.

Kelly was recruited to UCSF to serve as the Division Manager for DGIM in October 2013. Prior to joining us, Kelly was at the University of Washington from 2007-2013, where she was the department administrator for the Department of Medical Education and Biomedical Informatics and Department of Immunology. Kelly received her master’s degree in higher education administration and policy in 2006 and her bachelor’s degree in music performance and international studies in 1999 both from Northwestern University.

The new position of Division Manager with Heme/Onc is a significant promotion for Kelly and is a testament to her outstanding contributions to DGIM over the past 2+ years. We will miss her wisdom and savvy advice but wish her all the best in her new job.

DGIM News and Notes - November 2015

◇ Message From the Chief

I hope you enjoy the November edition of DGIM News and Notes. I decided to launch this monthly newsletter so that we can have a forum by which to learn about each others activities and accomplishments and to support a sense of community in the division. Keep sending your updates to us (me, Phil or Mai) by the 2nd Friday of the month.

As I write this, news is coming in about the unfolding tragedy in Paris. Some of you (like me) have a special connection to France through family and friends and this horrific event evokes even greater worry and sadness. In this month in which we celebrate Thanksgiving, we are all reminded of the fragility of life and the preciousness of our relationships with our families and friends, partners and colleagues. I am deeply grateful to all of you for your dedication to improving the health of our community through your work as clinicians, researchers and educators, and to all the staff for your support of this work. I hope you have a safe and peaceful Thanksgiving holiday.

Please click here for an update on some of the issues that are occupying my attention as your interim Division Chief.

◇ Announcements

Start diabetes screening for Asian Americans at a lower BMI
With new information from large studies in different Asian American groups, the American Diabetes Association recommended that all Asian Americans be screened for diabetes at a BMI of 23 kg/m2 rather than the 25 kg/m2 threshold recommended for all other race/ethnic groups. This recommendation was based on prospective data that showed that Asian Americans were at high risk of type 2 diabetes at this lower BMI, and that the sensitivity for diagnosing diabetes would be significantly improved. This month the USPSTF also recommended screening adults who are overweight or obese for abnormal glucose as part of a cardiovascular risk assessment (grade B recommendation). The Task Force did not specifically mention Asian Americans should start screening at BMI 23 kg/m2, but the World Health Organization has recommended that BMI of 23 kg/m2 be used to define overweight in Asians since 2004. We highly recommend that providers use a BMI 23 kg/m2 for Asian American patients as the trigger point to screen for diabetes (with a fasting glucose test) and to begin discussing lifestyle interventions for diabetes prevention.

For more information about the Screen at 23 campaign, visit the Screen at 23 website.

DGIM and Twitter - @UCSFDGIM
After considerable encouragement from our faculty to do a better job to disseminate our work and our achievements and create more of a community in DGIM, several of us have joined the social media age.

We have created a DGIM Twitter account (@UCSFDGIM) and we encourage you to join and follow to hear news about DGIM faculty, fellows and residents, follow each other and spread the news among your own social network.
Twitter Basics: (it's not as daunting as it sounds)

  • Sign up: www.twitter.com; choose a username and add a bio and picture
  • Find and follow people. Here are some of our faculty who are already using Twitter: @ARCHDrNguyen; @alka_kanaya; @mguyblueMD; @mitchellfeldma2; @MariaWamsley
  • Write a tweet: must stay under 140 characters
  • Mention someone: use the @ symbol plus their username anywhere in the Tweet
  • Retweet someone else's tweet to your followers: click the retweet double arrows
  • Hashtags: the # symbol marks keywords or topics to categorize messages

◇ New Grants in DGIM

Leah Karliner PI - NCI R21
Project Title: Disparities in Abnormal Mammogram Follow-up: Actionable Communication and Care Coordination Strategies.

The overarching goal of this proposal is to inform the development of a system intervention to decrease disparities in timeliness of abnormal mammogram follow-up for vulnerable women. This proposal is based in the San Francisco Mammography Registry (SFMR), a registry of all women having mammograms at twelve participating radiology facilities in two Northern California counties. Our preliminary work has categorized SFMR facilities as having either timely or delayed follow-up. This proposal builds upon that work by testing candidate actionable systems-based communication and care coordination strategies with women and referring physicians.

DGIM News and Notes - October 2015

◇ Announcements

Dr. Karen Hauer Earns PhD from UCSF-University of Utrecht Doctoral Program
Dr. Karen Hauer earned a PhD in medical education from the new UCSF-University of Utrecht doctoral program in September 2015.

The degree was awarded at a ceremony at the University of Utrecht, Netherlands. Two other doctoral candidates earned degrees, Carrie Chen from UCSF and Lauren Maggio from Stanford.

Dr. Hauer completed 6 manuscripts for the thesis and participated in the doctoral curriculum as part of this program. Her focus of study was the concept of trust in supervision. Her thesis was titled: "Evaluating Clinical Trainees in the Workplace: On Supervision, Trust and the Role of Competency Committees."

◇ Faculty Transitions

Dr. Veronica Yank Joins DGIM Faculty
We're happy to welcome Veronica Yank, MD, to DGIM. Dr. Yank is a general internist and health services researcher. Her research focuses on the development, testing, and implementation of interventions and delivery systems that boost patient and family activation and chronic disease self-management, particularly using methods optimized by technology.

Her studies address clinical conditions associated with elevated cardiovascular disease risk—including chronic kidney disease, obesity, and concurrent mental and physical health conditions.

DGIM News and Notes - September 2015

◇ Announcements

Dr. Paul Nadler Visits Peking Union Medical College Hospital
Paul Nadler was invited by the Division of General Internal Medicine at Peking Union Medical College Hospital (PUMCH) in Beijing, China to discuss primary care at UCSF.

While there, he described the UCSF DGIM Continuity Clinic, the Screening and Acute Care Clinic, and resident education in primary care.  He also presented the "One-Minute Preceptor" method, and demonstrated the technique in small group discussions and during patient presentations by residents. While at PUMCH, Paul participated in patient rounds and Grand Rounds.

Dr. Eliseo J. Peréz-Stable Welcomed at NIH

Francis Collins, MD, PhD, Director of National Institutes of Health welcomed Eliseo Perez-Stable as the new Director of the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities.

Dr. Collins shared the moment on his NIH Director Twitter feed

Eliseo Pérez-Stable's Director's Page at the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities can be found at http://www.nimhd.nih.gov/about/dirPage.html

Academy of Medical Educators Excellence in Teaching Awards Given to Drs. Leah Karliner and Scott Steiger

Leah Karliner and Scott Steiger are among the recipients of the Academy of Medical Educators 2015 Excellence in Teaching Awards.

The Excellence in Teaching Award was established in 2005. It is a peer-nominated award for UCSF teaching faculty, intended to highlight outstanding front-line teachers of medical students, residents, and fellows at UCSF.

Leah and Scott will receive their awards at the AME's 15th Annual Celebration of New Members that will be held on September 28th from 3–5pm at the Parnassus Campus Nursing Building Auditorium, room N-225.

A full list of this year's can be found at The Academy of Medical Educators' website

Dr. Alka Kanaya Named Human Research Core Co-Director of New Nutrition and Obesity Research Center

Alka Kanaya has been selected as the Human Research Core Co-Director of the newly created UCSF Nutrition and Obesity Research Center (NORC).

A grant from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases will provide funding for the new NORC, which will be part of the Diabetes Center at UCSF.

The UCSF NORC will be one of only 12 centers in the United States. To read more about Nutrition Obesity Research Centers, please visit http://www.norccentral.org/

Dr. Michael Rabow Participated in the National Comprehensive Cancer Network's Policy Summit

Mike Rabow participated in the National Comprehensive Cancer Network's Policy Summit on "Value, Access, and Cost of Cancer Care" at the National Press Club in Washington, DC on September 11, 2015.

Mike was part of a panel discussion about the "Cost Conundrum" in cancer care in the US. Other panelists included Steve Miller, the CEO of Express Scripts. Mike spoke about the cost avoidance and improved health system efficiency of early palliative care consultation. He and his co-authors have a paper in press showing improved care at the end of life and $5000 savings/patient referred to palliative care early (more than 3 months before death) vs. late (less than 3 months before death).

Dr. Edward Machtinger Presents Keynote at Futures Without Violence Conference

Edward Machtinger was the Keynote Speaker at the Futures Without Violence conference on September 11, 2015, presenting his talk "From Treatment to Healing: the Promise of Trauma-informed Primary Care."

Futures Without Violence has been working for more than 30 years to end violence against women and children. They have a Center for Leadership and Action in San Francisco's Presidio as well as offices in Washington, D.C. and Boston. More information about Futures Without Violence is available on their website http://www.futureswithoutviolence.org

Ellen Hughes Memorial

There will be a celebration of Dr. Ellen Hughes' life on Thursday, September 24, 2015 at 5:00pm in the Parnassus Campus Nursing Building Auditorium, room N-225. Everyone in the UCSF community is invited to honor and to reminisce about this remarkable woman whose kindness touched so many. A reception will follow in the Nursing Lobby.

The Ellen F. Hughes, M.D., PhD, Clinician Well-Being Lectureship and Award has been established in her honor. Donations can be sent to: UCSF Foundation, Attn. Ellen Hughes Lectureship Fund, P.O. Box 45339, San Francisco, CA 94145-0339.

◇ Faculty Transitions

Dr. Fayola Edwards-Ojeba Joins UCSF Women's Health
Fayola Edwards-Ojeba, MD, is a primary care physician and an assistant clinical professor of medicine at UCSF Women's Health.  She has a strong interest in creating a welcoming clinical practice that encourages all aspects of diversity.  She is active in the UCSF medical community in promoting improvement in minority, African-American, and women's health, as well as diversity within the medical community. 

Dr. Edwards-Ojeba earned her bachelor's degree from Harvard College, medical degree from the Yale University School of Medicine, and completed residency in internal medicine at UCSF.  She values being a member of a community dedicated to helping patients to achieve their goals of health and well-being. 

◇ New Grants in DGIM

Mitchell Feldman PI - NIH
Project Title: Mentoring the Mentors to Enhance Diversity in the Biomedical Research Workforce
A Collaboration Between the University of California and the NRMN has been selected to receive one of the NIH National Research Mentoring Network Pilot Awards under NIHMD009479 RFA. This proposal uniquely advances NRMN’s Mentor Training Core mission; to train mentors to work more effectively with underrepresented mentees engaged in biomedical research while specifically focusing on culturally responsible mentoring of graduate students, fellows, and junior clinician investigator faculty.
Steve Gregorich, Stuart Gansky, Co-PIs - NIDCR
Project Title: Multidisciplinary and Collaborative Research Consortium to Reduce Oral Health Disparities in Children.
The overall goal of this initiative is to establish effective interventions or programs to reduce or eliminate oral health disparities and inequalities in vulnerable U.S. children who are between 0 and 21 years of age. Multidisciplinary teams of investigators will refine and test an intervention or evaluate outcomes of an existing program or policy intended to reduce health disparities and inequalities.
 

◇ Focus on Fellows: 2015-16 Primary Care Research Fellows

  • Sachin K. Garg, MD. Sachin is a second-year primary care research fellow. He was born and raised in Chicago, IL, where he remained for undergraduate work in Economics at Northwestern University. He then worked as a strategy and management consultant before beginning medical school at Emory University and completing an Internal Medicine residency at the University of Pennsylvania. Sachin also worked as a primary care attending at the Palo Alto Medical Foundation before arriving at UCSF.

    His research interests are around the use of digital and other health technologies in chronic disease prevention, particularly cardiometabolic diseases. Several of Sachin's career and research mentors are based at Mt. Zion, including Alka Kanaya, Jeff Tice, and Mitch Feldman. In his free time, Sachin runs competitively, plays tennis and snowboards. He is also fascinated with airplanes!


    • Sachin Garg

    Yiwey Shieh and Jonathan Lee
  • Jonathan Lee, MD. Jonathan was born and raised in San Jose before leaving for Duke University for his undergraduate studies where he majored in biomedical engineering. He then made his way to the University of Pittsburgh for medical school, internal medicine residency and chief residency before returning to the Bay Area for the UCSF primary care fellowship. His research interests include quality of care and patient safety.  

  • Yiwey Shieh, MD. Yiwey is a first-year fellow in the Primary Care Research Program. His research interests revolve around cancer screening, especially the assessment of current screening strategies and ways to personalize decision-making through biomarkers and decision models. Prior projects were related to overdiagnosis in breast cancer screening, as well as the biology of cancers detected by mammography.

    Yiwey was raised in New Jersey, went to medical school at UCSF, and completed residency in internal medicine-primary care at the University of Pennsylvania. In his free time, he enjoys playing tennis, swimming, and exploring his new Inner Richmond neighborhood with his fiancée.
